notes.title: Classification and Nomenclature
points: Primary (1°), secondary (2°), and tertiary (3°) amines based on number of alkyl/aryl groups.
Aliphatic vs aromatic amines.
IUPAC nomenclature: Replace 'e' of alkane with 'amine' (e.g., methanamine, N-methylmethanamine).
Common names: Alkylamine (e.g., methylamine, dimethylamine).
Aromatic amines: Aniline (C₆H₅NH₂) as parent compound.

notes.title: Basic Character and Physical Properties
points: Basic nature due to lone pair on nitrogen.
Basicity order: Aliphatic amines > NH₃ > Aromatic amines.
Hydrogen bonding affects boiling points: 1° > 2° > 3°.
Solubility: Lower members are water-soluble due to H-bonding.
Unpleasant fishy odor, especially for lower aliphatic amines.

formulas.title: Basic Nature of Amines
formulas.explanation: Amines act as bases by accepting a proton from water, generating hydroxide ions and making the solution basic.

formulas.title: Hinsberg's Reagent Test
formulas.formula: RNH₂ + C₆H₅SO₂Cl + KOH → C₆H₅SO₂NHR (soluble in KOH, indicates 1° amine)
formulas.explanation: Used to distinguish between 1°, 2°, and 3° amines based on their reaction with benzenesulfonyl chloride (Hinsberg's reagent).

realworld.title: Traditional Dyeing Industry in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: The traditional Kalamkari and Kanchipuram silk industries in Tamil Nadu use aniline-based dyes, where aromatic amines serve as important intermediates in the synthesis of vibrant textile dyes.

notes.title: Formation and Structure
points: Formed by diazotization of primary aromatic amines with NaNO₂ and HCl at 0-5°C.
General formula: ArN₂⁺ X⁻ (X = Cl⁻, HSO₄⁻, BF₄⁻, etc.).
Benzenediazonium chloride (C₆H₅N₂⁺Cl⁻) as the most common example.
Unstable at room temperature, must be kept cold.
Sandmeyer and Gattermann reactions for replacement of diazonium group.

notes.title: Stability and Reactivity
points: Stabilized by resonance in aromatic systems.
N₂⁺ is a good leaving group, making diazonium salts highly reactive.
Undergo substitution reactions with various nucleophiles.
Formation of azo compounds (N=N) by coupling with phenols/amines.
Decomposition to form aryl halides, phenols, or arenes.

formulas.title: Diazotization Reaction
formulas.explanation: Formation of diazonium salt from primary aromatic amine using nitrous acid (generated in situ from NaNO₂ + H⁺).

formulas.title: Sandmeyer Reaction
formulas.formula: ArN₂⁺ + CuX → ArX + N₂↑ (X = Cl, Br, CN)
formulas.explanation: Replacement of diazonium group with -Cl, -Br, or -CN using copper(I) salts, useful for synthesizing aryl halides and nitriles.

realworld.title: Textile Industry in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Tiruppur and Coimbatore's textile industries extensively use azo dyes, which are synthesized from diazonium salts, for coloring cotton and other fabrics with bright, fast colors.

notes.title: Synthesis Methods
points: Reduction of nitro compounds: R-NO₂ → R-NH₂ (using Sn/HCl, Fe/HCl, or H₂/Ni).
Ammonolysis of alkyl halides: R-X + NH₃ → R-NH₃⁺X⁻ → R-NH₂ (excess NH₃).
Reduction of nitriles: R-CN → R-CH₂-NH₂ (using LiAlH₄ or H₂/Ni).
Gabriel phthalimide synthesis: For primary amines from alkyl halides.
Hofmann degradation of amides: R-CONH₂ + Br₂ + 4KOH → R-NH₂ + K₂CO₃ + 2KBr + 2H₂O.

notes.title: Chemical Properties
points: Basic character and salt formation with acids.
Alkylation: Formation of higher amines.
Acylation: Formation of amides.
Reaction with nitrous acid: Different products for 1°, 2°, and 3° amines.
Carbylamine test: For 1° amines (foul-smelling isocyanide formation).

formulas.title: Gabriel Phthalimide Synthesis
formulas.formula: C₆H₄(CO)₂NH + KOH → C₆H₄(CO)₂N⁻K⁺ + R-X → C₆H₄(CO)₂NR + KX → R-NH₂ (after hydrolysis)
formulas.explanation: Clean method to prepare pure primary amines from alkyl halides without over-alkylation.

formulas.title: Hofmann Mustard Oil Reaction
formulas.explanation: Test for primary amines, producing foul-smelling isothiocyanates (mustard oil-like compounds).

realworld.title: Pharmaceutical Industry in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu's pharmaceutical hub in Chennai produces various amine-containing drugs like antihistamines, antidepressants, and local anesthetics, utilizing different amine synthesis methods.

realworld.title: Traditional Medicine in Tamil Culture
realworld.description: Traditional Siddha medicine uses various plant-derived amines like ephedrine (from Sida species) and tryptamine derivatives, which have been used for centuries to treat various ailments.

notes.title: Replacement Reactions
points: Sandmeyer reaction: Formation of aryl halides, nitriles.
Gattermann reaction: Similar to Sandmeyer, uses Cu powder.
Schiemann reaction: Preparation of aryl fluorides.
Replacement by -OH: Formation of phenols by boiling with water.
Replacement by -H: Reduction to arenes using hypophosphorous acid (H₃PO₂).

notes.title: Coupling Reactions and Azo Dyes
points: Azo coupling with phenols in alkaline medium (pH 9-10).
Coupling with aromatic amines in weakly acidic medium (pH 4-5).
Formation of colored azo compounds (-N=N-).
Factors affecting coupling: pH, temperature, substituents.
Importance in dye industry: Methyl orange, Congo red, etc.

formulas.title: Formation of Azo Dye (Coupling Reaction)
formulas.explanation: Electrophilic aromatic substitution where diazonium cation attacks electron-rich aromatic rings to form brightly colored azo compounds.

formulas.title: Schiemann Reaction
formulas.explanation: Thermal decomposition of arenediazonium tetrafluoroborates to yield aryl fluorides, an important reaction in pharmaceutical synthesis.

realworld.title: Dye Manufacturing in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Industrial areas in Chennai and Coimbatore house several dye manufacturing units producing azo dyes from diazonium salts, supplying to both domestic textile industries and export markets.

realworld.title: Traditional Kalamkari Art
realworld.description: The traditional Kalamkari art form in Tamil Nadu, while primarily using natural dyes, has incorporated modern azo dyes for certain colors, demonstrating the practical applications of diazonium chemistry in preserving cultural heritage.

notes.title: Classification of Carbohydrates
points: Monosaccharides: Simple sugars (glucose, fructose, galactose) with 3-7 carbon atoms.
Disaccharides: Two monosaccharide units (sucrose, lactose, maltose).
Oligosaccharides: 3-10 monosaccharide units (raffinose, stachyose).
Polysaccharides: Long chains of monosaccharides (starch, cellulose, glycogen).
Reducing vs Non-reducing sugars: Based on presence of free aldehyde/ketone group.

notes.title: Structure and Functions
points: Glucose structure: Linear (Fischer) and cyclic (Haworth) forms, α and β anomers.
Glycosidic bond: Linkage between two monosaccharides.
Storage polysaccharides: Starch (plants), glycogen (animals).
Structural polysaccharides: Cellulose (plant cell walls), chitin (arthropods, fungi).
Biological roles: Energy source, energy storage, structural components, cell recognition.

formulas.title: General Formula of Carbohydrates
formulas.explanation: Represents the empirical formula of many carbohydrates, where n = number of carbon atoms. For example, glucose is C₆H₁₂O₆.

formulas.title: Reducing Sugar Test (Fehling's Test)
formulas.explanation: Reducing sugars reduce blue Cu²⁺ to red Cu₂O precipitate. Used to test for presence of reducing sugars like glucose and maltose.

realworld.title: Traditional Rice Varieties of Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu is home to numerous indigenous rice varieties like Seeraga Samba, Kullakar, and Karuppu Kavuni, which are rich in complex carbohydrates and have lower glycemic indices compared to modern varieties, making them healthier options.

realworld.title: Jaggery Production in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu's traditional jaggery (vellam) production from sugarcane and palm sap provides a natural source of sucrose, minerals, and antioxidants, serving as a healthier alternative to refined sugar.

notes.title: Amino Acids and Peptide Bond
points: 20 standard amino acids: Classified based on R-group (polar, nonpolar, acidic, basic).
Essential vs non-essential amino acids.
Peptide bond formation: Condensation reaction between amino and carboxyl groups.
Primary structure: Linear sequence of amino acids.
Secondary structure: α-helix and β-pleated sheets (stabilized by hydrogen bonds).

notes.title: Protein Structure and Functions
points: Tertiary structure: 3D folding of polypeptide chain (stabilized by disulfide bonds, ionic bonds, etc.).
Quaternary structure: Assembly of multiple polypeptide chains (e.g., hemoglobin).
Denaturation: Loss of protein structure due to heat, pH changes, etc.
Biological roles: Enzymes, structural components, transport, defense, regulation.
Protein deficiency diseases: Kwashiorkor, Marasmus.

formulas.title: Peptide Bond Formation
formulas.explanation: Condensation reaction between amino acids to form a dipeptide, with the elimination of a water molecule.

formulas.title: Biuret Test for Proteins
formulas.formula: Protein + CuSO₄ (in alkaline solution) → Violet color
formulas.explanation: The Biuret test detects the presence of peptide bonds in proteins, forming a violet-colored complex with copper ions in alkaline solution.

realworld.title: Traditional Protein Sources in Tamil Cuisine
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu's cuisine includes diverse plant-based protein sources like lentils (paruppu), legumes, and dairy products (curd, paneer), along with fish and eggs, providing a balanced amino acid profile.

realworld.title: Soybean Cultivation in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Soybean cultivation in districts like Krishnagiri and Dharmapuri provides a high-quality plant protein source, used in traditional dishes and as a meat substitute, addressing protein malnutrition.

notes.title: Nature and Classification
points: Biological catalysts: Speed up reactions without being consumed.
IUBMB classification: Oxidoreductases, transferases, hydrolases, lyases, isomerases, ligases.
Chemical nature: Mostly proteins, some are RNA (ribozymes).
Co-factors: Non-protein components (metal ions, coenzymes) required for activity.
Apoenzyme (protein part) + cofactor = holoenzyme.

notes.title: Mechanism and Factors Affecting Activity
points: Lock and key model vs induced fit model.
Factors affecting enzyme activity: Temperature, pH, substrate concentration, enzyme concentration.
Enzyme inhibition: Competitive, non-competitive, uncompetitive.
Allosteric regulation: Binding of effector molecules at sites other than active site.
Industrial applications: Food processing, detergents, paper industry, medicine.

formulas.title: Michaelis-Menten Equation
formulas.explanation: Describes how reaction velocity (v) depends on substrate concentration [S], where Vₘₐₓ is maximum velocity and Kₘ is Michaelis constant (substrate concentration at half Vₘₐₓ).

formulas.title: Lineweaver-Burk Plot
formulas.explanation: Double reciprocal plot used to determine Kₘ and Vₘₐₓ from enzyme kinetics data, where the y-intercept is 1/Vₘₐₓ and x-intercept is -1/Kₘ.

realworld.title: Traditional Fermentation in Tamil Cuisine
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu's traditional foods like idli, dosa, and vada rely on natural fermentation by enzymes from lactic acid bacteria and yeast, enhancing nutritional value and digestibility.

realworld.title: Enzyme Industry in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu hosts several enzyme manufacturing units producing industrial enzymes for textiles, leather processing, and food industries, contributing to the state's biotechnology sector.

notes.title: Classification and Functions
points: Fat-soluble vitamins: A, D, E, K (stored in liver and adipose tissue).
Water-soluble vitamins: B-complex and C (not stored, excess excreted).
Vitamin A: Vision, immune function, epithelial tissue maintenance.
B-complex: Coenzymes in energy metabolism.
Vitamin C: Collagen synthesis, antioxidant, immune function.
Vitamin D: Calcium absorption, bone health.
Vitamin E: Antioxidant, protects cell membranes.
Vitamin K: Blood clotting, bone metabolism.

notes.title: Deficiency Diseases and Sources
points: Vitamin A: Night blindness, xerophthalmia (carrots, sweet potatoes, leafy greens).
Thiamine (B1): Beriberi (whole grains, legumes, nuts).
Niacin (B3): Pellagra (meat, fish, nuts, whole grains).
Vitamin B12: Pernicious anemia (animal products, fortified foods).
Vitamin C: Scurvy (citrus fruits, amla, guava).
Vitamin D: Rickets, osteomalacia (sunlight, fish, fortified foods).
Vitamin K: Bleeding disorders (leafy greens, vegetable oils).

formulas.title: Structure of Ascorbic Acid (Vitamin C)
formulas.explanation: A six-carbon compound similar to glucose, containing an enediol group that makes it a strong reducing agent and antioxidant.

formulas.title: Retinol Activity Equivalents (RAE)
formulas.formula: 1 μg RAE = 1 μg retinol = 12 μg β-carotene = 24 μg α-carotene
formulas.explanation: Measures vitamin A activity in foods, accounting for differences in absorption and conversion of various provitamin A carotenoids.

realworld.title: Traditional Vitamin-Rich Foods in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Tamil cuisine includes vitamin-rich traditional foods like drumstick leaves (vitamin A), ragi (B vitamins), and amla (vitamin C), which have been part of the local diet for centuries to prevent deficiencies.

realworld.title: Fortification Programs in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: The Tamil Nadu government's fortification of staples like rice (with iron, folic acid, vitamin B12) and milk (with vitamin D) addresses micronutrient deficiencies, especially among women and children.

notes.title: DNA and RNA Structure
points: DNA: Double helix (Watson-Crick model), deoxyribose sugar, A-T, G-C base pairing.
RNA: Usually single-stranded, ribose sugar, A-U, G-C base pairing.
Nucleotides: Phosphate group + pentose sugar + nitrogenous base.
Nitrogenous bases: Purines (adenine, guanine), pyrimidines (cytosine, thymine, uracil).
Chargaff's rules: A=T, G=C in DNA; A=U, G=C in RNA.

notes.title: DNA Replication and Protein Synthesis
points: Semi-conservative replication: Each new DNA molecule has one old and one new strand.
Central dogma: DNA → RNA → Protein.
Transcription: Synthesis of mRNA from DNA template.
Translation: Protein synthesis at ribosomes using mRNA, tRNA, and rRNA.
Genetic code: Triplet codon system, universal, degenerate, non-overlapping.

formulas.title: Chargaff's Rule
formulas.explanation: In double-stranded DNA, the amount of adenine equals thymine, and guanine equals cytosine, maintaining the double helix structure.

formulas.title: Melting Temperature (Tm) of DNA
formulas.explanation: The temperature at which 50% of DNA becomes single-stranded. G-C pairs (3 hydrogen bonds) increase Tm more than A-T pairs (2 hydrogen bonds).

realworld.title: Genome Sequencing of Indigenous Crops
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu Agricultural University has been involved in genome sequencing of traditional rice varieties like Seeraga Samba, helping preserve genetic diversity and develop climate-resilient crops.

realworld.title: Genetic Research in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Research institutions in Tamil Nadu, including the Centre for Cellular and Molecular Biology (CCMB) regional center in Chennai, conduct cutting-edge research on genetic disorders prevalent in the local population, such as beta-thalassemia and sickle cell anemia.

notes.title: Based on Source
points: Natural polymers: Found in nature (e.g., proteins, cellulose, natural rubber, silk).
Semi-synthetic polymers: Chemically modified natural polymers (e.g., cellulose acetate, vulcanized rubber).
Synthetic polymers: Man-made through polymerization (e.g., polythene, nylon, PVC).

notes.title: Based on Structure
points: Linear polymers: Long, straight chains with minimal branching (e.g., HDPE, nylon).
Branched polymers: Linear chains with side branches (e.g., LDPE, glycogen).
Cross-linked polymers: 3D network structure (e.g., bakelite, vulcanized rubber).

notes.title: Based on Molecular Forces
points: Elastomers: Weak intermolecular forces, highly elastic (e.g., natural rubber, neoprene).
Fibers: Strong hydrogen bonding, high tensile strength (e.g., nylon-6,6, terylene).
Thermoplastics: Soften on heating, harden on cooling (e.g., PVC, polythene).
Thermosetting plastics: Irreversible cross-linking, don't soften on heating (e.g., bakelite, melamine).

realworld.title: Traditional Rubber Industry in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: The rubber plantations in Kanyakumari and Nilgiris districts produce high-quality natural rubber, which is processed in local factories for various applications, contributing significantly to the state's economy.

notes.title: Addition Polymerisation
points: Involves repeated addition of monomers with double/triple bonds.
No byproducts formed.
Examples: Polythene (from ethene), PVC (from vinyl chloride), Teflon (from tetrafluoroethene).
Mechanism: Free radical, cationic, or anionic polymerisation.
Chain growth process: Initiation, propagation, termination.

notes.title: Condensation Polymerisation
points: Involves the elimination of small molecules like water, ammonia, etc.
Forms copolymers with repeating units different from monomers.
Examples: Nylon-6,6 (hexamethylenediamine + adipic acid), Terylene (ethylene glycol + terephthalic acid).
Step-growth process: Monomers react to form dimers, trimers, and eventually long chains.
Requires bifunctional or polyfunctional monomers.

notes.title: Co-polymerisation
points: Involves two or more different monomers.
Types: Random, alternating, block, and graft copolymers.
Examples: Buna-S (styrene + butadiene), Nylon-6,6 (hexamethylenediamine + adipic acid).
Properties can be tailored by varying monomer ratios.
Widely used in specialty applications requiring specific properties.

formulas.title: Degree of Polymerisation (DP)
formulas.formula: DP = Molecular weight of polymer / Molecular weight of monomer
formulas.explanation: Indicates the number of repeating units in a polymer chain. Higher DP generally means higher molecular weight and different physical properties.

formulas.title: Nylon-6,6 Formation
formulas.explanation: Condensation reaction between hexamethylenediamine and adipic acid, with the elimination of water molecules.

realworld.title: Polymer Industries in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu's industrial hubs in Chennai, Coimbatore, and Tiruppur house numerous polymer processing units manufacturing products ranging from plastic containers to automotive components, leveraging various polymerisation techniques.

notes.title: Types of Synthetic Fibres
points: Polyamides: Nylon-6 (from caprolactam), Nylon-6,6 (strong, elastic, used in ropes, fabrics).
Polyesters: Terylene/Dacron (ethylene glycol + terephthalic acid), used in clothing, bottles.
Acrylics: Polyacrylonitrile (PAN), wool substitute (e.g., Orlon, Acrilan).
Modacrylics: Flame-resistant fibres (e.g., Dynel, Verel).
Spandex: Polyurethane, highly elastic (e.g., Lycra).

notes.title: Properties and Applications
points: High tensile strength and durability.
Resistant to moths, chemicals, and environmental conditions.
Can be engineered for specific properties (water resistance, flame retardancy).
Used in textiles, ropes, fishing nets, tire cords, and medical applications.
Blending with natural fibres enhances properties (e.g., poly-cotton blends).

formulas.title: Nylon-6 Formation
formulas.explanation: Ring-opening polymerisation of ε-caprolactam to form Nylon-6, widely used in textiles and industrial applications.

realworld.title: Tiruppur Textile Cluster
realworld.description: Tiruppur, known as the 'Knitwear Capital of India', extensively uses synthetic fibres like polyester and nylon in its textile manufacturing, contributing significantly to India's textile exports.

notes.title: Types of Plastics
points: Thermoplastics: Can be remelted and remolded (e.g., PVC, polythene, polystyrene).
Thermosetting plastics: Set permanently when heated (e.g., bakelite, melamine, urea-formaldehyde).
Engineering plastics: High-performance plastics (e.g., polycarbonate, ABS).
Biodegradable plastics: Break down naturally (e.g., PLA, PHA).
Commodity plastics: High-volume, low-cost (e.g., PET, HDPE, PP).

notes.title: Rubbers and Elastomers
points: Natural rubber: Polyisoprene, obtained from latex of Hevea brasiliensis.
Vulcanization: Process of heating rubber with sulfur to improve properties.
Synthetic rubbers: Neoprene (chloroprene), Buna-S (styrene-butadiene), Buna-N (nitrile rubber).
Properties: Elasticity, water resistance, electrical insulation.
Applications: Tires, hoses, footwear, medical devices.

notes.title: Environmental Impact and Recycling
points: Non-biodegradability of conventional plastics leads to pollution.
Microplastics: Tiny plastic particles harming marine life.
Recycling codes: PET (1), HDPE (2), PVC (3), LDPE (4), PP (5), PS (6), Others (7).
Biodegradable alternatives: PLA, PHA, starch-based polymers.
Government initiatives: Plastic waste management rules, ban on single-use plastics.

formulas.title: Polyethylene Formation
formulas.explanation: Addition polymerisation of ethylene (ethene) to form polyethylene, the most common plastic.

formulas.title: Vulcanization Reaction
formulas.formula: Rubber + S₈ → Vulcanized Rubber (Cross-linked with -Sx- bridges)
formulas.explanation: Sulfur forms cross-links between polymer chains, improving elasticity and heat resistance of natural rubber.

realworld.title: Plastic Recycling in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu has implemented several plastic waste management initiatives, including the 'Green Tamil Nadu Mission', promoting recycling and proper disposal of plastic waste. Cities like Chennai have established plastic waste collection and recycling facilities.

realworld.title: Automotive Component Manufacturing
realworld.description: The automotive hub in and around Chennai extensively uses engineering plastics and synthetic rubbers for manufacturing various components, including dashboards, bumpers, and hoses, contributing to the state's industrial growth.

notes.title: Classification of Drugs
points: Based on pharmacological effect: Analgesics, antipyretics, antibiotics, etc.
Based on drug action: Antagonists, agonists, enzyme inhibitors.
Based on chemical structure: Sulpha drugs, barbiturates, benzodiazepines.
Based on molecular targets: Enzymes, receptors, nucleic acids.
Based on therapeutic use: Antacids, antihistamines, tranquilizers.

notes.title: Commonly Used Medicines
points: Analgesics: Paracetamol, aspirin, ibuprofen (pain relief).
Antibiotics: Penicillin, tetracycline, ofloxacin (treat bacterial infections).
Antiseptics: Dettol, tincture of iodine, boric acid (prevent infection).
Disinfectants: Phenol, chlorine, formaldehyde (kill microorganisms).
Antacids: Ranitidine, omeprazole, milk of magnesia (reduce stomach acid).

formulas.title: pH Calculation for Antacids
formulas.explanation: Antacids work by neutralizing excess stomach acid (HCl), increasing pH from about 1.5 to 3.5, which provides relief from acidity.

realworld.title: Pharmaceutical Industry in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu's pharmaceutical hub in Chennai and nearby areas produces about 50% of India's total vaccine requirements and 20% of the country's total pharmaceutical production, including essential drugs and formulations.

notes.title: Mechanism of Drug Action
points: Drug-enzyme interaction: Competitive and non-competitive inhibition.
Drug-receptor interaction: Agonists and antagonists.
Targeting specific biomolecules: Enzymes, receptors, nucleic acids.
Physical and chemical properties affecting drug action: Solubility, partition coefficient, drug stability.
Therapeutic index: Ratio of toxic dose to therapeutic dose.

notes.title: Drug-Target Interaction
points: Enzyme inhibitors: Competitive (sulphanilamide), non-competitive (cyanide).
Receptor proteins: Histamine receptors, adrenergic receptors.
Ion channels: Calcium channel blockers (nifedipine).
Nucleic acids: Anticancer drugs (cisplatin).
Membrane lipids: General anesthetics.

formulas.title: Therapeutic Index
formulas.explanation: Where TD₅₀ is the median toxic dose and ED₅₀ is the median effective dose. Higher TI indicates safer drug.

realworld.title: Traditional Medicine Research in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: The Central Council for Research in Siddha, Chennai, conducts scientific validation of traditional Siddha formulations, studying their therapeutic actions and developing standardized herbal medicines with proven efficacy.

notes.title: Types of Food Additives
points: Preservatives: Sodium benzoate, potassium metabisulphite, sodium nitrite.
Artificial sweeteners: Saccharin, aspartame, sucralose.
Food colors: Allura red, tartrazine, indigo carmine.
Antioxidants: BHA, BHT, vitamin E, vitamin C.
Flavor enhancers: Monosodium glutamate (MSG), inosine monophosphate.

notes.title: Functions and Safety
points: Improve shelf life and prevent spoilage.
Enhance flavor, color, and texture.
Provide essential nutrients (fortification).
Regulatory bodies: FSSAI in India, FDA in USA.
Acceptable Daily Intake (ADI) and safety evaluation.

formulas.title: ADI Calculation
formulas.explanation: NOAEL (No Observed Adverse Effect Level) is the highest dose at which no adverse effects are observed. The safety factor accounts for differences between test animals and humans.

realworld.title: Food Processing Industry in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu's food processing industry, particularly in Namakkal (egg processing), Erode (turmeric), and Theni (fruits), extensively uses food additives while adhering to FSSAI standards for quality and safety.

notes.title: Types of Cleansing Agents
points: Soaps: Sodium or potassium salts of fatty acids (stearic acid, palmitic acid).
Synthetic detergents: Anionic (sodium lauryl sulfate), cationic (cetyltrimethylammonium bromide), non-ionic (PEG).
Biological detergents: Contain enzymes (proteases, lipases).
Toothpaste: Contains abrasives, fluorides, detergents, and flavoring agents.
Shampoos: Contain surfactants, conditioners, and preservatives.

notes.title: Mechanism of Action
points: Micelle formation: Hydrophobic tail attaches to oil/grease, hydrophilic head faces water.
Emulsification: Oil droplets are suspended in water.
Hard water issues: Soaps form scum with Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺ ions.
Advantages of synthetic detergents: Work in hard water, more soluble, better cleansing action.
Environmental impact: Biodegradability and eutrophication concerns.

formulas.title: Micelle Formation
formulas.explanation: The minimum concentration of surfactant above which micelles form. Below CMC, surfactant molecules exist as monomers; above CMC, they aggregate to form micelles.

formulas.title: Hard Water Reaction with Soap
formulas.explanation: Calcium stearate (insoluble soap scum) forms when soap reacts with calcium ions in hard water, reducing cleaning efficiency.

realworld.title: Soap and Detergent Industry in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu hosts several major detergent manufacturing units, including Hindustan Unilever in Oragadam, producing popular brands while implementing sustainable practices like water recycling and biodegradable formulations.

realworld.title: Traditional Soap Making in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Traditional Ayurvedic and herbal soap making using natural ingredients like neem, turmeric, and sandalwood continues to thrive in Tamil Nadu, with small-scale industries in Madurai and Coimbatore preserving these age-old formulations.

notes.title: Introduction to Reproduction
points: Reproduction is a biological process where new organisms (offspring) are produced from their parents.
Ensures continuity of species and maintains the population of organisms.
Two main types: Asexual (single parent) and Sexual (two parents).
Asexual reproduction is common in unicellular organisms and some multicellular organisms.
Sexual reproduction is predominant in complex multicellular organisms.

notes.title: Significance of Reproduction
points: Maintains the continuity of life on Earth.
Leads to genetic variation through sexual reproduction.
Helps in evolution by allowing beneficial traits to be passed on.
Enables species to adapt to changing environments.
Ensures ecological balance by maintaining population sizes.

realworld.title: Conservation Efforts in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu's conservation programs in the Western Ghats and Nilgiri Biosphere Reserve help protect various species' reproductive habitats, ensuring their survival and reproduction.

notes.title: Types of Asexual Reproduction
points: Binary Fission: Division of parent cell into two equal daughter cells (e.g., Amoeba, Paramecium).
Budding: Outgrowth from parent that detaches (e.g., Hydra, Yeast).
Fragmentation: Breaking of parent body into pieces that grow into new individuals (e.g., Spirogyra, Planaria).
Spore Formation: Production of spores that develop into new organisms (e.g., Fungi, Ferns).
Vegetative Propagation: New plants from vegetative parts like roots, stems, leaves (e.g., Potato tubers, Bryophyllum leaves).

notes.title: Advantages and Disadvantages
points: Advantages: Rapid multiplication, no need for mate, preserves genetic stability of successful genotypes.
Disadvantages: No genetic variation, less adaptability to environmental changes, accumulation of harmful mutations.
Common in stable environments where adaptation is less critical.
Used in agriculture for producing genetically identical crop plants.
Important for organisms with limited mobility or those that are sessile.

formulas.title: Population Growth in Asexual Reproduction
formulas.explanation: Where N is the final population, N₀ is the initial number of organisms, and n is the number of generations. Shows exponential growth under ideal conditions.

realworld.title: Tissue Culture in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu Agricultural University (TNAU) uses tissue culture for mass propagation of disease-free banana and sugarcane plants, significantly benefiting local farmers with higher yields.

notes.title: Features of Sexual Reproduction
points: Involves fusion of male and female gametes (syngamy).
Leads to genetic variation due to meiosis and fertilization.
Two main types: Isogamy (similar gametes) and Anisogamy (dissimilar gametes).
Oogamy: Fusion of large non-motile egg and small motile sperm.
Hermaphroditism: Both sexes in same individual (e.g., Earthworm, Tapeworm).

notes.title: Events in Sexual Reproduction
points: Pre-fertilization: Gametogenesis (formation of gametes) and gamete transfer.
Fertilization: Fusion of gametes to form zygote (syngamy).
Post-fertilization: Zygote development into embryo and then to new individual.
External fertilization: Occurs outside the body (e.g., fish, amphibians).
Internal fertilization: Occurs inside the female body (e.g., reptiles, birds, mammals).

formulas.title: Genetic Variation Calculation
formulas.explanation: Represents the number of possible gamete combinations due to independent assortment during meiosis in diploid organisms.

realworld.title: Paddy Cultivation in Cauvery Delta
realworld.description: Traditional paddy varieties in Tamil Nadu's Cauvery delta region show how selective breeding (artificial selection) has been used for centuries to develop strains with desirable traits like drought resistance and high yield.

topics.name: Life Cycles of Plants and Animals

notes.title: Plant Life Cycles
points: Haplontic: Dominant haploid phase (e.g., Volvox, Spirogyra).
Diplontic: Dominant diploid phase (e.g., Gymnosperms, Angiosperms).
Haplo-diplontic: Alternation of generations (e.g., Bryophytes, Pteridophytes).
Sporic meiosis: Meiosis produces spores that grow into gametophytes.
Gametic meiosis: Meiosis produces gametes directly.

notes.title: Animal Life Cycles
points: Zygotic meiosis: Haploid adults produce gametes by mitosis (e.g., some protozoans).
Gametic meiosis: Diploid adults produce haploid gametes by meiosis (most animals).
Metamorphosis: Drastic change in form during development (e.g., frog: egg → tadpole → adult).
Direct development: Young resemble adults (e.g., humans, birds).
Parthenogenesis: Development of egg without fertilization (e.g., honeybees, some lizards).

realworld.title: Silkworm Rearing in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu's sericulture industry, particularly in Dharmapuri and Salem districts, depends on understanding the life cycle of silkworms (Bombyx mori) for successful silk production, from egg to cocoon formation.

realworld.title: Mangrove Conservation in Pichavaram
realworld.description: The unique reproductive adaptations of mangrove species in Pichavaram, including vivipary (seeds germinate while still attached to parent plant), are crucial for their survival in saline coastal environments and are key to conservation efforts.

notes.title: Structure and Functions
points: Primary sex organs: Testes (produce sperm and testosterone).
Accessory ducts: Epididymis, vas deferens, ejaculatory duct, and urethra (transport and store sperm).
Accessory glands: Seminal vesicles, prostate gland, and bulbourethral glands (secrete seminal fluid).
External genitalia: Penis and scrotum.
Spermatogenesis: Process of sperm production in seminiferous tubules.

notes.title: Hormonal Control
points: Hypothalamus releases GnRH (Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone).
Anterior pituitary secretes FSH (stimulates spermatogenesis) and LH (stimulates testosterone production).
Testosterone: Responsible for male secondary sexual characteristics and sperm production.

realworld.title: Male Infertility in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Increasing cases of male infertility in Tamil Nadu have been linked to environmental factors, lifestyle changes, and pollution, leading to a rise in fertility treatments in the state.

notes.title: Structure and Functions
points: Primary sex organs: Ovaries (produce ova and female hormones).
Accessory ducts: Fallopian tubes, uterus, and vagina.
External genitalia: Labia majora, labia minora, clitoris, and hymen.
Mammary glands: For lactation after childbirth.
Oogenesis: Process of ovum formation in the ovaries.

notes.title: Hormonal Regulation
points: Hypothalamus releases GnRH.
Anterior pituitary secretes FSH (stimulates follicular development) and LH (triggers ovulation).
Ovarian hormones: Estrogen (regulates menstrual cycle) and progesterone (prepares uterus for pregnancy).

realworld.title: Women's Health Initiatives in TN
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu's Amma Two-Wheeler Scheme has improved access to healthcare for rural women, positively impacting maternal and reproductive health outcomes in the state.

notes.title: Spermatogenesis
points: Occurs in seminiferous tubules of testes.
Stages: Spermatogonia → Primary spermatocytes → Secondary spermatocytes → Spermatids → Spermatozoa.
Duration: Approximately 64 days in humans.
Spermiogenesis: Transformation of spermatids into mature sperm.
Hormonal control: FSH and testosterone regulate the process.

notes.title: Oogenesis
points: Begins in fetal life, completes after puberty.
Stages: Oogonia → Primary oocytes (arrested in prophase I) → Secondary oocyte (arrested in metaphase II) → Ovum.
One ovum is produced per menstrual cycle.
Polar bodies are formed during oogenesis.
Hormonal control: FSH and LH regulate the process.

realworld.title: Fertility Awareness in TN
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu's school health programs include reproductive health education, helping students understand gametogenesis and fertility from an early age.

notes.title: Phases of Menstrual Cycle
points: Menstrual phase (Days 1-5): Shedding of uterine lining.
Follicular phase (Days 6-13): Development of ovarian follicles.
Ovulation (Day 14): Release of secondary oocyte from ovary.
Luteal phase (Days 15-28): Formation of corpus luteum.
Average cycle length: 28 days (can vary from 21-35 days).

notes.title: Hormonal Control
points: FSH: Stimulates follicular development and estrogen secretion.
LH: Triggers ovulation and corpus luteum formation.
Estrogen: Thickens endometrium during follicular phase.
Progesterone: Maintains endometrium during luteal phase.
If no pregnancy, corpus luteum degenerates, causing menstruation.

formulas.title: Fertile Window Calculation
formulas.explanation: Ovulation typically occurs 14 days before the next menstrual period. The fertile window includes 2 days before and after ovulation.

realworld.title: Menstrual Hygiene in Rural TN
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu's free sanitary napkin distribution program has significantly improved menstrual hygiene and reduced school absenteeism among adolescent girls.

notes.title: Process of Fertilisation
points: Occurs in the ampullary-isthmic junction of fallopian tube.
Sperm undergoes capacitation and acrosomal reaction.
Fusion of sperm and ovum membranes → Formation of zygote.
Completion of second meiotic division of secondary oocyte.
Formation of male and female pronuclei, followed by syngamy.

notes.title: Cleavage and Implantation
points: Zygote undergoes mitotic divisions (cleavage) as it moves towards uterus.
Forms morula (16-32 cells) and then blastocyst.
Blastocyst consists of inner cell mass (embryo) and trophoblast (forms placenta).
Implantation occurs 6-7 days after fertilisation in the endometrium.
Trophoblast secretes hCG to maintain corpus luteum.

realworld.title: IVF Success Rates in Chennai
realworld.description: Chennai's fertility clinics report success rates comparable to global standards, with specialized treatments for various infertility issues common in the region.

notes.title: Placenta and Extraembryonic Membranes
points: Placenta: Forms from chorionic villi and uterine tissue, facilitates nutrient/waste exchange.
Amnion: Forms amniotic sac filled with amniotic fluid.
Chorion: Outer membrane that forms fetal part of placenta.
Allantois: Contributes to umbilical cord formation.
Yolk sac: Early blood cell formation and germ cell migration.

notes.title: Embryonic Development
points: Week 1-2: Cleavage, blastocyst formation, and implantation.
Week 3: Gastrulation (formation of three germ layers).
Week 4-8: Organogenesis (development of major organs).
Week 9-birth: Fetal period (growth and maturation of organs).
Critical periods of development when teratogens can cause birth defects.

realworld.title: Maternal Health in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu's comprehensive prenatal care program has significantly reduced maternal and neonatal mortality rates through regular check-ups and nutritional support.

notes.title: Parturition (Childbirth)
points: Average gestation period: 280 days (40 weeks) from last menstrual period.
Stages of labor: Dilation of cervix, delivery of baby, delivery of placenta.
Hormonal control: Oxytocin from posterior pituitary stimulates uterine contractions.
Relaxin: Softens cervix and pelvic ligaments.
Positive feedback mechanism: Stretching of cervix stimulates more oxytocin release.

notes.title: Lactation
points: Mammary glands develop during pregnancy under influence of estrogen and progesterone.
Prolactin: Stimulates milk production (lactogenesis).
Oxytocin: Stimulates milk ejection (let-down reflex).
Colostrum: First milk rich in antibodies (passive immunity to newborn).
Benefits of breastfeeding for both mother and child.

realworld.title: Breastfeeding Initiatives in TN
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu's 'Amma Baby Care Centers' in workplaces and public spaces support working mothers to continue breastfeeding, contributing to improved child health indicators.

notes.title: Concept of Reproductive Health
points: Reproductive health refers to complete physical, mental, and social well-being in all matters related to the reproductive system.
It includes the ability to have a satisfying and safe sex life, capability to reproduce, and freedom to decide if, when, and how often to do so.
Components include family planning, counseling, education about reproductive health, and prevention of sexually transmitted diseases.

notes.title: Importance of Reproductive Health
points: Ensures healthy reproduction and proper development of offspring.
Reduces maternal and infant mortality rates.
Prevents sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and reproductive tract infections (RTIs).
Promotes gender equality and women's empowerment.
Helps in population control and sustainable development.

realworld.title: Reproductive Health in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu has been a pioneer in implementing reproductive health programs like the Tamil Nadu Health Systems Project, which significantly improved maternal and child health indicators.

notes.title: Causes of Population Explosion
points: Decline in death rate due to better medical facilities.
Decrease in infant mortality rate (IMR) and maternal mortality rate (MMR).
Increased life expectancy.
Lack of education and awareness about family planning.
Early marriage and childbearing.

notes.title: Consequences of Population Growth
points: Pressure on natural resources and environment.
Increased demand for food, water, and energy.
Unemployment and poverty.
Overcrowding in urban areas.
Strain on healthcare and education systems.

formulas.title: Population Growth Rate
formulas.formula: Birth Rate - Death Rate + Net Migration Rate
formulas.explanation: The rate at which a population grows in a given time period, usually expressed as a percentage.

realworld.title: Tamil Nadu's Population Control Success
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu achieved replacement level fertility (2.1 children per woman) much earlier than other Indian states due to effective family planning programs and women's education initiatives.

notes.title: Natural Methods
points: Periodic abstinence: Avoiding intercourse during the fertile period.
Lactational amenorrhea: Temporary infertility after childbirth when breastfeeding.
Withdrawal method: Withdrawing the penis before ejaculation.
Basal body temperature method: Tracking body temperature to identify fertile days.

notes.title: Barrier Methods
points: Condoms (male and female): Prevent sperm from entering the uterus.
Diaphragms, cervical caps, and vaults: Barrier methods for females.
Spermicidal creams, jellies, and foams: Kill or immobilize sperm.

notes.title: Intrauterine Devices (IUDs)
points: Copper T: Releases copper ions that suppress sperm motility.
Hormonal IUDs: Release progestin to prevent ovulation and thicken cervical mucus.
Non-hormonal IUDs: Work by causing a mild inflammatory reaction in the uterus.

notes.title: Oral Contraceptives
points: Combined pills: Contain estrogen and progestin to prevent ovulation.
Mini-pills: Contain only progestin, which thickens cervical mucus.
Emergency contraceptive pills: Used after unprotected intercourse.

notes.title: Surgical Methods
points: Tubectomy: Blocking or cutting the fallopian tubes in females.
Vasectomy: Cutting or blocking the vas deferens in males.
Both are permanent methods of contraception.

realworld.title: Contraceptive Use in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu has one of the highest rates of contraceptive use in India, with female sterilization being the most common method, followed by condoms and oral pills.

notes.title: Common STDs
points: Bacterial: Gonorrhea, Syphilis, Chlamydia, Chancroid.
Viral: HIV/AIDS, Genital herpes, Genital warts, Hepatitis B.
Protozoan: Trichomoniasis.
Fungal: Candidiasis.
Ectoparasites: Scabies, Pubic lice.

notes.title: Symptoms and Prevention
points: Common symptoms: Sores or bumps on genitals, painful urination, unusual discharge, itching, and pain during intercourse.
Prevention: Safe sex practices, using condoms, regular testing, and vaccination (for Hepatitis B and HPV).
Importance of early detection and treatment to prevent complications.
Partner notification and treatment to prevent reinfection.

notes.title: HIV/AIDS
points: Caused by Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV).
Attacks the immune system, specifically CD4 cells.
Transmission through blood, semen, vaginal fluids, and breast milk.
No cure, but antiretroviral therapy (ART) can control the virus.
Importance of prevention through education and safe practices.

realworld.title: Tamil Nadu AIDS Control Society (TANSACS)
realworld.description: TANSACS has implemented successful awareness and prevention programs, making Tamil Nadu a model state in HIV/AIDS control in India.

notes.title: Causes of Infertility
points: Male factors: Low sperm count, poor sperm motility, blockages, hormonal imbalances.
Female factors: Ovulation disorders, blocked fallopian tubes, uterine abnormalities, endometriosis.
Age-related factors: Declining fertility with age, especially after 35 in women.
Lifestyle factors: Smoking, alcohol, obesity, stress, and environmental factors.

notes.title: Assisted Reproductive Technologies (ART)
points: In Vitro Fertilization (IVF): Fertilization outside the body in a laboratory.
Intrauterine Insemination (IUI): Placing sperm directly into the uterus.
Gamete Intrafallopian Transfer (GIFT): Transfer of eggs and sperm into fallopian tubes.
Zygote Intrafallopian Transfer (ZIFT): Transfer of fertilized eggs into fallopian tubes.
Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection (ICSI): Direct injection of sperm into an egg.
Surrogacy: Another woman carries and delivers a baby for the intended parents.
Sperm/Egg Donation: Using donor gametes for conception.

notes.title: Ethical and Legal Aspects
points: Issues of multiple pregnancies and selective reduction.
Risks of ART to mother and child.
Legal status of surrogacy and gamete donation in India.
Ethical concerns regarding designer babies and sex selection.
Importance of counseling and informed consent.

realworld.title: Fertility Centers in Tamil Nadu
realworld.description: Tamil Nadu has several advanced fertility centers offering ART services, with Chennai emerging as a hub for reproductive medicine in South India, attracting patients from across the country and abroad.

Biology.title: Unit 4: Principles of Inheritance and Variation

notes.title: Mendel's Experimental Approach
points: Used Pisum sativum (garden pea) for experiments
Studied 7 contrasting traits over 7 years (1856-1863)
Used true-breeding plants and maintained careful records
Conducted reciprocal crosses to study inheritance patterns

notes.title: Key Terms
points: Alleles: Alternative forms of a gene
Homozygous: Identical alleles (TT or tt)
Heterozygous: Different alleles (Tt)
Phenotype: Observable characteristic
Genotype: Genetic constitution

realworld.title: Plant Breeding
realworld.description: Mendel's principles are used to develop new plant varieties with desired traits like disease resistance and higher yield.

notes.title: Mendel's Three Laws
points: Law of Dominance: In a heterozygote, one allele is expressed over the other
Law of Segregation: Alleles separate during gamete formation
Law of Independent Assortment: Genes for different traits assort independently

formulas.title: Punnett Square Ratio
formulas.formula: Monohybrid cross (Aa x Aa) → 1:2:1 genotypic, 3:1 phenotypic ratio
formulas.explanation: For a single gene with complete dominance, the expected ratio of offspring genotypes is 1 (AA) : 2 (Aa) : 1 (aa), while the phenotype ratio is 3 (dominant) : 1 (recessive).

realworld.title: Genetic Counseling
realworld.description: Understanding Mendelian laws helps predict the probability of genetic disorders in offspring.

notes.title: Monohybrid Cross
points: Involves single pair of contrasting traits
F1 generation shows dominant trait
F2 generation shows 3:1 phenotypic ratio
Test cross ratio is 1:1 for complete dominance

notes.title: Incomplete Dominance
points: Neither allele is completely dominant
Phenotype is a blend of parental traits
Example: Snapdragon flower color (red x white = pink)
F2 ratio becomes 1:2:1 (genotypic and phenotypic)

realworld.title: Flower Color in Snapdragons
realworld.description: Red and white snapdragons produce pink offspring, demonstrating incomplete dominance in flower color inheritance.

notes.title: Dihybrid Cross
points: Involves two pairs of contrasting traits
F1 generation shows both dominant traits
F2 generation shows 9:3:3:1 phenotypic ratio
Demonstrates independent assortment

notes.title: Linkage and Recombination
points: Genes on same chromosome tend to be inherited together
Recombination occurs due to crossing over
Recombination frequency indicates distance between genes
Used to create genetic maps

formulas.title: Recombination Frequency
formulas.formula: Recombination % = (Number of recombinant offspring / Total offspring) × 100
formulas.explanation: Used to calculate the distance between linked genes on a chromosome. 1 map unit = 1% recombination frequency.

realworld.title: Disease Gene Mapping
realworld.description: Used to locate disease-causing genes by studying their inheritance patterns with known genetic markers.

notes.title: Types of Non-Mendelian Inheritance
points: Incomplete Dominance: Intermediate phenotype (e.g., snapdragon flowers)
Co-dominance: Both alleles expressed equally (e.g., AB blood group)
Multiple Alleles: More than two alleles exist (e.g., ABO blood groups)
Pleiotropy: Single gene affects multiple traits (e.g., sickle cell anemia)
Polygenic Inheritance: Multiple genes affect single trait (e.g., skin color, height)

realworld.title: Human Blood Groups
realworld.description: ABO blood group system demonstrates both multiple alleles (IA, IB, i) and co-dominance (IA and IB are co-dominant).

notes.title: Key Postulates
points: Chromosomes carry hereditary factors (genes)
Chromosomes segregate and assort independently during meiosis
Chromosomes maintain genetic continuity from generation to generation
Proposed by Sutton and Boveri (1902)

notes.title: Evidence
points: Parallel behavior of chromosomes and Mendelian factors
Sex-linked inheritance patterns
Chromosome mapping data
Correlation between gene and chromosome behavior

realworld.title: Drosophila Research
realworld.description: Thomas Hunt Morgan's work with fruit flies provided evidence for the chromosomal theory of inheritance.

notes.title: Mechanisms of Sex Determination
points: XX-XY system: Humans, mammals (XX female, XY male)
ZZ-ZW system: Birds, butterflies (ZZ male, ZW female)
XX-XO system: Grasshoppers (XX female, XO male)
Haplodiploidy: Bees, ants (fertilized eggs become females, unfertilized become males)
Environmental: Temperature-dependent in some reptiles

notes.title: Sex-linked Inheritance
points: Genes located on sex chromosomes show specific patterns
X-linked recessive disorders more common in males (hemophilia, color blindness)
Fathers pass X-linked genes to all daughters but no sons
Mothers pass X-linked genes to both sons and daughters

realworld.title: Color Blindness
realworld.description: More common in males because they have only one X chromosome. Females need two copies of the allele to express the trait.

notes.title: Key Experiments
points: Griffith's Transformation Experiment (1928): Demonstrated transformation in bacteria
Avery, MacLeod, and McCarty (1944): Identified DNA as the transforming principle
Hershey-Chase Experiment (1952): Confirmed DNA as genetic material using bacteriophages

notes.title: Properties of Genetic Material
points: Should be able to replicate accurately
Chemically and structurally stable
Provide scope for mutations
Express itself in the form of 'Mendelian characters'

realworld.title: Forensic Science
realworld.description: Uses unique DNA patterns to identify individuals, used in criminal investigations and paternity tests.

notes.title: DNA Structure
points: Double helix model by Watson and Crick (1953)
Composed of nucleotides (sugar-phosphate backbone with nitrogenous bases)
Base pairing: A-T (2 hydrogen bonds), G-C (3 hydrogen bonds)
Antiparallel strands with 5' to 3' and 3' to 5' orientation

notes.title: RNA Structure and Types
points: Single-stranded structure
Types: mRNA (messenger), tRNA (transfer), rRNA (ribosomal)
Contains uracil (U) instead of thymine (T)
Ribose sugar instead of deoxyribose

formulas.title: Chargaff's Rules
formulas.formula: A = T, G = C, A + G = T + C
formulas.explanation: In DNA, the amount of adenine equals thymine, and guanine equals cytosine.

realworld.title: Personalized Medicine
realworld.description: Understanding DNA structure allows for personalized treatment based on individual genetic makeup.

notes.title: Semi-conservative Replication
points: Each new DNA molecule has one old and one new strand
Proved by Meselson and Stahl's experiment (1958)
Enzymes involved: DNA helicase, DNA polymerase, DNA ligase, topoisomerase

notes.title: Process of Replication
points: Initiation: Origin of replication (ori) site unwinds
Elongation: DNA polymerase adds nucleotides in 5' to 3' direction
Leading and lagging strand synthesis (Okazaki fragments)
Termination: DNA ligase joins Okazaki fragments

realworld.title: Cancer Treatment
realworld.description: Many chemotherapy drugs target rapidly dividing cancer cells by interfering with DNA replication.

notes.title: Process of Transcription
points: Initiation: RNA polymerase binds to promoter region
Elongation: RNA synthesis in 5' to 3' direction
Termination: Rho-dependent and Rho-independent mechanisms
In eukaryotes: Pre-mRNA undergoes processing (capping, tailing, splicing)

notes.title: Types of RNA Polymerase
points: RNA polymerase I: Synthesizes rRNA (except 5S rRNA)
RNA polymerase II: Synthesizes mRNA and snRNA
RNA polymerase III: Synthesizes tRNA, 5S rRNA, and other small RNAs

realworld.title: Reverse Transcription
realworld.description: HIV uses reverse transcriptase to convert its RNA into DNA, which then integrates into host genome.

notes.title: Components Required
points: mRNA: Carries genetic code
tRNA: Transfers amino acids
Ribosomes: Site of protein synthesis
Amino acids: Building blocks of proteins
Enzymes and protein factors

notes.title: Stages of Translation
points: Initiation: Ribosome assembles around mRNA, first tRNA binds to start codon (AUG)
Elongation: Amino acids are added one by one to the growing polypeptide chain
Termination: Release factor binds to stop codon, polypeptide is released

realworld.title: Antibiotics Action
realworld.description: Many antibiotics like tetracycline and streptomycin target bacterial translation machinery to stop protein synthesis.

notes.title: Characteristics
points: Triplet: Three nucleotides code for one amino acid
Universal: Same in most organisms
Degenerate: Multiple codons can code for same amino acid
Non-overlapping: Each nucleotide is part of only one codon
Comma-less: No punctuation between codons

notes.title: Wobble Hypothesis
points: Proposed by Francis Crick (1966)
Explains how multiple codons can be read by a single tRNA
First two bases of codon form strong bonds, third base can 'wobble'

formulas.title: Number of Possible Codons
formulas.explanation: 4 possible nucleotides (A, U, G, C) in each of 3 positions gives 64 possible combinations.

realworld.title: Synthetic Biology
realworld.description: Scientists have created organisms with expanded genetic codes that include unnatural amino acids.

notes.title: Lac Operon Model
points: Discovered by Jacob and Monod (1961)
Inducible operon in E. coli for lactose metabolism
Components: Promoter, operator, structural genes (lacZ, lacY, lacA)
Regulated by repressor protein and cAMP-CAP complex

notes.title: Eukaryotic Gene Regulation
points: Transcriptional level: Histone modification, DNA methylation
Post-transcriptional: Alternative splicing, RNA editing
Translational level: microRNAs, RNA interference
Post-translational: Protein modification, degradation

realworld.title: Cancer Therapy
realworld.description: Drugs targeting DNA methylation and histone modifications are used to treat cancers caused by abnormal gene expression.

notes.title: Theories of Origin of Life
points: Theory of Special Creation: Life was created by a supernatural power
Theory of Spontaneous Generation: Life arises from non-living matter
Panspermia Theory: Life came from outer space through meteorites
Oparin-Haldane Theory: Life originated from inorganic molecules in primitive Earth's atmosphere

notes.title: Miller-Urey Experiment
points: Simulated early Earth's atmosphere (methane, ammonia, hydrogen, water vapor)
Used electric sparks to simulate lightning
Produced amino acids and organic compounds
Supported chemical evolution theory

realworld.title: Deep Sea Vents
realworld.description: Hydrothermal vents in deep oceans may have provided the right conditions for life's origin, with mineral-rich water and temperature gradients.

notes.title: Lamarckism
points: Theory of inheritance of acquired characters
Use and disuse of organs leads to evolution
Example: Giraffe's long neck due to stretching

notes.title: Darwinism
points: Natural selection as mechanism of evolution
Survival of the fittest
Variation and adaptation in populations

notes.title: Modern Synthetic Theory
points: Combines Darwin's natural selection with genetics
Includes genetic variation, mutation, genetic drift, and gene flow
Considers population genetics

realworld.title: Peppered Moth Evolution
realworld.description: During industrial revolution, dark-colored moths became more common than light-colored ones due to better camouflage on soot-covered trees.

notes.title: Key Concepts
points: Variation exists in populations
Organisms produce more offspring than can survive
Competition for limited resources
Differential survival and reproduction

notes.title: Types of Selection
points: Stabilizing selection: Favors average phenotypes
Directional selection: Favors one extreme phenotype
Disruptive selection: Favors both extremes

realworld.title: Antibiotic Resistance
realworld.description: Bacteria evolve resistance to antibiotics through natural selection, where resistant strains survive and reproduce while non-resistant ones die.

notes.title: Hardy-Weinberg Equilibrium
points: p² + 2pq + q² = 1
p + q = 1
p = frequency of dominant allele
q = frequency of recessive allele

notes.title: Assumptions
points: No mutations
Random mating
No natural selection
Large population size
No gene flow

formulas.title: Hardy-Weinberg Equations
formulas.explanation: Where p² is the frequency of homozygous dominant genotype, 2pq is the frequency of heterozygous genotype, and q² is the frequency of homozygous recessive genotype.

realworld.title: Sickle Cell Anemia in Malaria Regions
realworld.description: The high frequency of sickle cell allele in malaria-endemic regions demonstrates Hardy-Weinberg principle with heterozygote advantage.

notes.title: Hominid Evolution
points: Australopithecus: First bipedal hominids
Homo habilis: First tool users
Homo erectus: First to use fire
Homo neanderthalensis: Lived in Europe and Asia
Homo sapiens: Modern humans

notes.title: Key Features of Human Evolution
points: Bipedal locomotion
Increased brain size
Reduced jaw size
Development of culture and language

realworld.title: Lactose Tolerance in Adults
realworld.description: The ability to digest lactose in adulthood evolved independently in different populations that domesticated dairy animals, showing recent human evolution.

notes.title: Common Human Diseases
points: Bacterial diseases: Typhoid (Salmonella typhi), Pneumonia (Streptococcus pneumoniae)
Viral diseases: Common cold (Rhino viruses), AIDS (HIV)
Protozoan diseases: Malaria (Plasmodium), Amoebiasis (Entamoeba histolytica)

Emerging and re-emerging diseases in India

Incubation periods of common diseases

Government health programs in India
Disease surveillance and reporting systems

Microscopic examination and culture methods

Antibiotics and antimicrobial resistance
Traditional and alternative medicine systems in India
Rational use of medicines

realworld.title: Malaria Control in India

realworld.title: TB Elimination Program

realworld.title: COVID-19 Pandemic Response
realworld.description: India's response to COVID-19 included nationwide lockdowns, testing strategies, vaccination drives (world's largest), and digital tools like Aarogya Setu for contact tracing and health monitoring.

notes.title: Types of Immunity
points: Innate immunity: First line of defense (skin, mucous membranes, phagocytes)
Acquired immunity: Humoral (B-cells) and cell-mediated (T-cells)
Active immunity: Develops after exposure to pathogen or vaccination
Passive immunity: Transfer of antibodies (maternal, antiserum)
Herd immunity and community protection
Vaccine-preventable diseases in India

notes.title: Immune System Components
points: Lymphoid organs: Bone marrow, thymus, lymph nodes, spleen
White blood cells: Lymphocytes, phagocytes, granulocytes
Antibodies: Structure and functions of IgG, IgM, IgA, IgE, IgD
Cytokines and complement system
Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC)
Autoimmunity and immunodeficiency disorders

notes.title: Vaccination and Immunization

National Immunization Schedule of India
Mission Indradhanush: Immunization program
Vaccine development and testing
Vaccine hesitancy and misinformation
Global vaccination initiatives

realworld.title: Pulse Polio Programme
realworld.description: India was declared polio-free in 2014 after years of intensive vaccination campaigns, including National Immunization Days and house-to-house vaccination, demonstrating successful public health intervention.

realworld.title: COVID-19 Vaccination Drive
realworld.description: India administered over 2 billion COVID-19 vaccine doses through the world's largest vaccination drive, utilizing digital platforms like CoWIN for registration and certification, with both domestic (Covaxin) and imported vaccines (Covishield).

realworld.title: Mission Indradhanush
realworld.description: Launched in 2014, this program aims to immunize all children under 2 years and pregnant women against 12 vaccine-preventable diseases, focusing on low-coverage areas and vulnerable populations across India.

notes.title: Mechanism of Allergy
points: Type I hypersensitivity reaction
Role of IgE antibodies and mast cells
Release of histamine and other mediators
Common allergens: Pollen, dust mites, food, insect stings, drugs
Genetic predisposition (atopy)
Hygiene hypothesis and increasing allergy prevalence

notes.title: Common Allergic Conditions
points: Allergic rhinitis (hay fever)
Asthma and its triggers
Atopic dermatitis (eczema)
Food allergies (peanuts, shellfish, etc.)
Anaphylaxis: Life-threatening allergic reaction
Drug allergies and cross-reactivity

notes.title: Diagnosis and Management
points: Skin prick tests and patch tests
Serum IgE levels (RAST test)
Elimination diets for food allergies
Pharmacotherapy: Antihistamines, corticosteroids, bronchodilators
Immunotherapy (allergy shots)
Allergy prevention strategies

realworld.title: Air Pollution and Respiratory Allergies
realworld.description: Rising air pollution levels in Indian cities like Delhi have been linked to increased prevalence of respiratory allergies and asthma, particularly in children, highlighting the need for better air quality management.

realworld.title: Food Allergy Awareness

Applications in disease diagnosis, genetic testing, and personalized medicine.

formulas.title: PCR Amplification
formulas.formula:
Final DNA amount = Initial DNA amount × (2^n)
Where n = number of PCR cycles
formulas.explanation: Calculates the theoretical DNA amplification in PCR reactions.

formulas.title: Therapeutic Index
formulas.formula:
Therapeutic Index (TI) = TD50 / ED50
Where:
TD50 = Toxic dose for 50% of population
ED50 = Effective dose for 50% of population
formulas.explanation: Measures drug safety; higher values indicate greater safety margin.

formulas.title: Antibody Titer

formulas.explanation: Measures the concentration of antibodies in a sample, important in vaccine efficacy and disease diagnosis.

Herbicide-Tolerant Crops: Resistant to specific herbicides (e.g., Roundup Ready crops).

Germplasm Conservation: Cryopreservation of plant genetic resources.
Applications in horticulture, forestry, and medicinal plants.

notes.title: Marker-Assisted Selection (MAS)
points: DNA markers linked to desirable traits (e.g., disease resistance, yield).

Examples of MAS in rice, wheat, and other crops.
Advantages over conventional breeding methods.

notes.title: Biofertilizers and Biopesticides
points: Nitrogen-fixing bacteria: Rhizobium, Azotobacter, Azospirillum.
Phosphate-solubilizing microorganisms.
Mycorrhizal fungi: Enhance nutrient and water uptake.
Biocontrol agents: Trichoderma, Pseudomonas, Bacillus thuringiensis.
Advantages: Eco-friendly, sustainable, cost-effective.
Government initiatives and subsidies in India.

formulas.title: Heritability
formulas.formula:
h² = Vg / Vp
Where:
h² = Heritability
Vg = Genetic variance
Vp = Phenotypic variance (Vp = Vg + Ve + Vge)
formulas.explanation: Measures the proportion of phenotypic variation due to genetic factors.

formulas.title: Selection Differential
formulas.formula:
S = Xs - X
Where:
S = Selection differential
Xs = Mean of selected parents
X = Population mean
formulas.explanation: Measures the strength of selection in a breeding program.

formulas.title: Expected Genetic Gain
formulas.formula:
ΔG = h² × S
Where:
ΔG = Expected genetic gain
h² = Heritability
S = Selection differential
formulas.explanation: Predicts the response to selection in a breeding program.

formulas.title: Biodiversity Index

formulas.explanation: Measures species diversity, important for assessing ecological impacts of biotechnology.

notes.title: Introduction to Ecology
points: Ecology is the study of interactions among organisms and between organisms and their physical environment.
The term was coined by German biologist Ernst Haeckel in 1866.
Ecology operates at multiple levels: organisms → populations → communities → ecosystems → biomes → biosphere.
Abiotic factors (non-living) and biotic factors (living) shape the environment.
Major abiotic factors include temperature, water, light, soil, and wind.

notes.title: Organism's Response to Environment
points: Adaptations: Structural, physiological, and behavioral traits that enhance survival.
Regulation: Maintaining homeostasis through physiological means (e.g., thermoregulation).
Conformity: Allowing internal conditions to vary with external changes.
Migration: Seasonal movement to avoid unfavorable conditions.
Dormancy: Temporary reduction in metabolic activity during unfavorable periods.
Hibernation (winter sleep) and Aestivation (summer sleep) are examples of dormancy.

notes.title: Major Biomes of the World
points: Tropical Rainforest: High rainfall, high biodiversity, found near the equator.
Desert: Low precipitation, extreme temperature variations.
Grassland: Dominated by grasses, moderate rainfall, supports grazing animals.
Temperate Forest: Four distinct seasons, deciduous trees.
Tundra: Permafrost, low-growing vegetation, long winters.
India has diverse biomes including tropical rainforests, deserts, and alpine tundra.

notes.title: Ecological Niche
points: The role and position a species has in its environment.
Includes all of its interactions with biotic and abiotic factors.
Fundamental Niche: The full range of environmental conditions under which an organism can exist.
Realized Niche: The actual conditions under which an organism exists due to competition.
Competitive Exclusion Principle: Two species cannot coexist if they occupy the same niche.
Resource Partitioning: Division of limited resources by species to reduce competition.

formulas.title: Shelford's Law of Tolerance
formulas.formula: For each environmental factor, organisms have a minimum, maximum, and optimum range.
formulas.explanation: Organisms can only survive within a specific range of environmental conditions.

formulas.title: Liebig's Law of the Minimum
formulas.formula: Growth is controlled by the scarcest resource (limiting factor).
formulas.explanation: Even if all other factors are favorable, the limiting factor will determine growth and distribution.

formulas.title: Niche Breadth
formulas.formula: B = 1/Σ(pi)² where pi is the proportion of individuals found in resource state i
formulas.explanation: Measures the diversity of resources used by a species.

notes.title: Population Characteristics
points: Population Density: Number of individuals per unit area or volume.
Natality (Birth rate): Number of births per 1000 individuals per year.
Mortality (Death rate): Number of deaths per 1000 individuals per year.
Age Distribution: Proportion of individuals in different age groups.
Sex Ratio: Number of males per 1000 females in a population.
Population Growth: Determined by births, deaths, immigration, and emigration.

notes.title: Population Growth Models
points: Exponential Growth: J-shaped curve, occurs when resources are unlimited (dN/dt = rN).
Logistic Growth: S-shaped curve, accounts for limited resources (dN/dt = rN((K-N)/K)).
Carrying Capacity (K): Maximum population size an environment can sustain.
Boom-and-Bust Cycles: Rapid growth followed by sudden decline, common in some species.
r-selected species: High growth rate, many offspring, little parental care.
K-selected species: Low growth rate, few offspring, extensive parental care.

notes.title: Life History Strategies
points: Life Table: Shows age-specific mortality and survival rates.
Survivorship Curves: Type I (low mortality in early life), Type II (constant mortality), Type III (high mortality in early life).
Age Pyramids: Show age and sex distribution of a population.
Reproductive Strategies: Semelparity (single reproductive event) vs. Iteroparity (multiple reproductive events).
Trade-offs: Between number and size of offspring, current and future reproduction, etc.

notes.title: Human Population Growth
points: Demographic Transition: Shift from high birth/death rates to low birth/death rates.
Population Pyramids: Show age and sex structure of human populations.
Total Fertility Rate (TFR): Average number of children born to a woman.
Infant Mortality Rate: Number of deaths of children under one year per 1000 live births.
Doubling Time: Time required for a population to double in size.
India's population trends and demographic challenges.

formulas.title: Population Growth Rate
formulas.formula:
r = (b - d) + (i - e)
Where:
r = growth rate
b = birth rate
d = death rate
i = immigration rate
e = emigration rate
formulas.explanation: Calculates the per capita rate of population change.

formulas.title: Exponential Growth
formulas.formula:
Nt = N₀e^(rt)
Where:
Nt = population at time t
N₀ = initial population
r = intrinsic rate of increase
t = time
formulas.explanation: Describes population growth when resources are unlimited.

formulas.title: Logistic Growth
formulas.formula:
dN/dt = rN((K-N)/K)
Where:
dN/dt = rate of population change
r = intrinsic rate of increase
N = population size
K = carrying capacity
formulas.explanation: Describes population growth when resources are limited.

notes.title: Ecosystem Components
points: Biotic Components: Living organisms (producers, consumers, decomposers).
Abiotic Components: Non-living physical and chemical factors.
Producers (Autotrophs): Convert solar energy into chemical energy (plants, algae, cyanobacteria).
Consumers (Heterotrophs): Depend on producers for food (herbivores, carnivores, omnivores).
Decomposers: Break down dead organic matter (bacteria, fungi).
Detritivores: Feed on detritus (earthworms, millipedes).

notes.title: Ecological Succession
points: Primary Succession: Occurs on newly exposed land (lava flows, glacial retreat).
Secondary Succession: Occurs after a disturbance (fire, flood, agriculture).
Pioneer Species: First to colonize barren areas (lichens, mosses).
Climax Community: Stable, mature community in equilibrium with the environment.
Seral Stages: Intermediate stages in succession.
Hydrarch Succession: In water bodies. Xerarch Succession: On dry land.

notes.title: Biogeochemical Cycles
points: Water Cycle: Evaporation, condensation, precipitation, runoff, infiltration.
Carbon Cycle: Photosynthesis, respiration, decomposition, combustion.
Nitrogen Cycle: Nitrogen fixation, nitrification, denitrification, ammonification.
Phosphorus Cycle: Weathering of rocks, absorption by plants, movement through food chains.
Human impacts on biogeochemical cycles (e.g., fossil fuel combustion, fertilizer use).

notes.title: Ecological Services
points: Provisioning Services: Food, water, timber, fiber, genetic resources.
Regulating Services: Climate regulation, flood control, disease regulation, water purification.
Supporting Services: Nutrient cycling, soil formation, primary production.
Cultural Services: Recreational, aesthetic, and spiritual benefits.
Economic value of ecosystem services (e.g., pollination, water purification).
Threats to ecosystem services from human activities.

formulas.title: Net Primary Productivity (NPP)
formulas.formula:
NPP = GPP - R
Where:
NPP = Net Primary Productivity
GPP = Gross Primary Productivity
R = Respiration
formulas.explanation: Measures the rate at which biomass is generated by primary producers.

formulas.title: Ecological Efficiency
formulas.formula: Ecological Efficiency = (Energy at higher trophic level / Energy at lower trophic level) × 100
formulas.explanation: Percentage of energy transferred from one trophic level to the next (typically 10%).

formulas.title: Species Diversity Index (Shannon-Wiener)
formulas.formula:
H' = -Σ(pi × ln(pi))
Where:
H' = Shannon Diversity Index
pi = proportion of individuals of species i
ln = natural logarithm
formulas.explanation: Measures species diversity in a community, accounting for both abundance and evenness.

notes.title: Trophic Levels
points: Producers (First Trophic Level): Autotrophs that capture solar energy.
Primary Consumers (Second Level): Herbivores that feed on producers.
Secondary Consumers (Third Level): Carnivores that feed on herbivores.
Tertiary Consumers (Fourth Level): Top carnivores that feed on other carnivores.
Decomposers: Break down dead organic matter at all levels.
Food Chain: Linear sequence of who eats whom in an ecosystem.

notes.title: Food Webs and Energy Transfer
points: Food Web: Complex network of interconnected food chains.
10% Law: Only about 10% of energy is transferred from one trophic level to the next.
Energy Pyramids: Show the decrease in available energy at successive trophic levels.
Biomass Pyramids: Show the total dry mass of organisms at each trophic level.
Numbers Pyramids: Show the number of individual organisms at each level.
Ecological Efficiency: Percentage of energy transferred from one level to the next.

notes.title: Ecological Pyramids
points: Pyramid of Energy: Always upright, shows energy content at each trophic level.
Pyramid of Biomass: Usually upright, but can be inverted (e.g., in aquatic ecosystems).
Pyramid of Numbers: Can be upright or inverted depending on the ecosystem.
Standing Crop: Amount of living material present at each trophic level at a given time.
Standing State: Amount of inorganic nutrients present in the environment.
Factors affecting ecological pyramids: Season, ecosystem type, and human activities.

notes.title: Biogeochemical Cycles and Energy Flow
points: Energy flows through ecosystems in one direction (sun → producers → consumers).
Nutrients cycle through ecosystems in biogeochemical cycles.
Energy is lost as heat at each trophic level (Second Law of Thermodynamics).
Ecological efficiency limits the number of trophic levels (typically 4-5).
Human activities can disrupt energy flow through pollution, habitat destruction, and overharvesting.
Sustainable practices aim to maintain natural energy flows and nutrient cycles.

formulas.title: Energy Transfer Efficiency
formulas.formula: Transfer Efficiency = (Energy at higher level / Energy at lower level) × 100
formulas.explanation: Calculates the percentage of energy transferred between trophic levels (typically ~10%).

formulas.title: Ecological Efficiency
formulas.formula: Ecological Efficiency = (Production at trophic level n / Production at trophic level n-1) × 100
formulas.explanation: Measures the efficiency of energy transfer between trophic levels.

formulas.title: Lindeman's Efficiency
formulas.formula: Lindeman's Efficiency = (Ingestion at level n / Ingestion at level n-1) × 100
formulas.explanation: Measures the efficiency of energy transfer based on ingestion rates.

notes.title: Types of Ecological Pyramids
points: Pyramid of Numbers: Shows the number of individual organisms at each trophic level.
Pyramid of Biomass: Represents the total dry weight of organisms at each trophic level.
Pyramid of Energy: Illustrates the amount of energy at each trophic level.
Upright Pyramid: Typical for most terrestrial ecosystems (e.g., grassland, forest).
Inverted Pyramid: Can occur in some ecosystems (e.g., parasitic food chains, some aquatic systems).
Partially Inverted Pyramid: When lower trophic levels have less biomass than higher levels.

notes.title: Pyramid of Numbers
points: Represents the number of individual organisms at each trophic level.
Usually upright but can be inverted (e.g., a single tree supporting many herbivores).
Limitations: Doesn't account for size differences between organisms.
Example: Grass (large numbers) → Grasshoppers (fewer) → Frogs (even fewer) → Snakes (fewest).
Inverted example: Tree (one) → Birds (many) → Parasites (many more).
Useful for understanding population structure but limited in showing energy flow.

notes.title: Pyramid of Biomass
points: Represents the total dry weight of organisms at each trophic level.
Usually upright in terrestrial ecosystems.
Can be inverted in aquatic ecosystems where producers (phytoplankton) have high turnover rates.
Expressed in grams per square meter (g/m²) or other area/volume units.
Standing Crop: Biomass present at a given time.
Limitations: Doesn't account for productivity or turnover rates.

notes.title: Pyramid of Energy
points: Most accurate representation of ecosystem structure.
Always upright due to the Second Law of Thermodynamics (energy is lost as heat).
Expressed in kilocalories per square meter per year (kcal/m²/yr).
Accounts for energy lost as heat at each trophic level.
Shows the actual energy available to each trophic level.
Useful for comparing different ecosystems and understanding energy flow efficiency.

formulas.title: Biomass Calculation
formulas.formula: Biomass = Number of individuals × Average weight per individual
formulas.explanation: Calculates the total biomass at a given trophic level.

formulas.title: Ecological Efficiency Between Trophic Levels
formulas.formula: Ecological Efficiency = (Energy at higher level / Energy at lower level) × 100
formulas.explanation: Calculates the percentage of energy transferred between trophic levels.

formulas.title: Turnover Rate
formulas.explanation: Measures how quickly biomass is replaced in a population or trophic level.
