notes.title: Introduction to Biodiversity
points: Biodiversity refers to the variety and variability of life on Earth at all levels, from genes to ecosystems.
The term was coined by Walter G. Rosen in 1985 and popularized by Edward O. Wilson.
Biodiversity is essential for ecosystem functioning and provides numerous ecosystem services.
It is often used as a measure of the health of biological systems.
Biodiversity is not evenly distributed, with the greatest concentration found in tropical regions.

notes.title: Genetic Diversity
points: Genetic diversity refers to the variety of genes within a species.
It includes the differences in DNA among individuals within a species population.
Important for species' adaptation to changing environments and resistance to diseases.
Example: Different breeds of dogs or varieties of rice show genetic diversity.
Conservation of genetic diversity is crucial for crop improvement and medicine.

notes.title: Species Diversity
points: Species diversity refers to the variety of species within a region or ecosystem.
It includes both species richness (number of species) and species evenness (relative abundance).
Tropical rainforests and coral reefs are examples of species-rich ecosystems.
Species diversity is important for ecosystem stability and productivity.
Endemic species (found only in specific locations) are particularly important for conservation.

notes.title: Ecosystem Diversity
points: Ecosystem diversity refers to the variety of ecosystems in a given place.
Includes diversity at the landscape level, such as forests, deserts, wetlands, etc.
Each ecosystem has its own characteristic species and ecological processes.
Important for maintaining ecological balance and providing various ecosystem services.
Example: The Western Ghats in India show high ecosystem diversity.

formulas.title: Species Richness Index
formulas.formula: S = Number of different species in the community
formulas.explanation: A simple count of species present in a given area.

formulas.title: Shannon Diversity Index (H')
formulas.formula: H' = -Σ(pi × ln(pi)) where pi = proportion of individuals of species i to total individuals
formulas.explanation: Measures species diversity that accounts for both abundance and evenness.

formulas.title: Simpson's Diversity Index (D)
formulas.formula: D = 1 - Σ(n/N)² where n = number of individuals of each species, N = total number of individuals
formulas.explanation: Measures the probability that two randomly selected individuals belong to the same species.

realworld.title: Ecotourism
realworld.description: Regions with high biodiversity, like the Amazon rainforest or the Great Barrier Reef, attract tourists, generating significant economic benefits for local communities.

notes.title: Latitudinal Gradient
points: Biodiversity generally increases from the poles to the equator.
Tropical regions (between 23.5°N and 23.5°S) have the highest biodiversity.
Reasons include more stable climate, higher productivity, and greater evolutionary time.
Example: Tropical rainforests cover less than 10% of Earth's surface but contain about 50% of all species.
This pattern is observed for most groups of organisms, including plants, insects, and vertebrates.

notes.title: Species-Area Relationship
points: Larger areas generally contain more species than smaller ones.
Described by the equation S = cA^z, where S is species richness, A is area, and c and z are constants.
The value of z typically ranges from 0.1 to 0.2 for most groups of organisms.
Important for conservation planning and designing protected areas.
Example: Islands typically have fewer species than mainland areas of similar size.

notes.title: Global Biodiversity Hotspots
points: Regions with high species richness and high endemism that are under significant threat.
To qualify as a hotspot, a region must contain at least 1,500 species of vascular plants as endemics and have lost at least 70% of its original habitat.
There are 36 recognized biodiversity hotspots worldwide.
Example: The Western Ghats and Sri Lanka hotspot in India.
These areas are conservation priorities due to high biodiversity and high threat levels.

notes.title: India's Biodiversity
points: India is one of the 17 megadiverse countries in the world.
Contains 7-8% of all recorded species, including over 45,000 species of plants and 91,000 species of animals.
Four biodiversity hotspots: Himalayas, Indo-Burma, Western Ghats-Sri Lanka, and Sundaland.
Home to several endemic species like the Lion-tailed Macaque and Nilgiri Tahr.
Rich in agro-biodiversity with numerous traditional crop varieties and breeds of livestock.

formulas.title: Species-Area Relationship
formulas.formula:
S = cA^z
Where:
S = Number of species
A = Area
c = Constant (y-intercept on log-log plot)
z = Slope of the line (typically 0.1-0.2)
formulas.explanation: Describes how species richness increases with area.

formulas.title: Endemism Index
formulas.formula: Endemism = (Number of endemic species / Total number of species) × 100
formulas.explanation: Measures the percentage of species in a region that are endemic.

formulas.title: Beta Diversity
formulas.formula:
β = (S1 - c) + (S2 - c)
Where:
S1 = Number of species in community 1
S2 = Number of species in community 2
c = Number of species common to both communities
formulas.explanation: Measures the change in species composition between different communities.

notes.title: Causes of Biodiversity Loss
points: Habitat destruction: The primary cause, including deforestation, urbanization, and agricultural expansion.
Overexploitation: Overhunting, overfishing, and overharvesting of species.
Invasive species: Non-native species that outcompete native species for resources.
Pollution: Contamination of air, water, and soil affecting species survival.
Climate change: Altering habitats and affecting species' life cycles.
Population growth: Increased human population leading to greater resource consumption.

notes.title: The IUCN Red List Categories
points: Extinct (EX): No known individuals remaining.
Extinct in the Wild (EW): Known only to survive in captivity.
Critically Endangered (CR): Extremely high risk of extinction in the wild.
Endangered (EN): High risk of extinction in the wild.
Vulnerable (VU): High risk of endangerment in the wild.
Near Threatened (NT): Likely to become endangered in the near future.
Least Concern (LC): Lowest risk; widespread and abundant.
Data Deficient (DD): Not enough data to assess risk.

notes.title: Biodiversity Loss in India
points: India has lost significant forest cover, though recent afforestation efforts have helped.
Many species are threatened, including the Bengal Tiger, Asian Elephant, and Indian Rhinoceros.
Wetland loss has been significant, affecting both biodiversity and water resources.
Marine biodiversity is threatened by overfishing and coastal development.
Climate change is affecting species' distributions and migration patterns.

notes.title: Consequences of Biodiversity Loss
points: Ecosystem instability and reduced resilience to environmental changes.
Loss of ecosystem services like clean air, water purification, and soil fertility.
Reduced food security due to loss of crop varieties and wild food sources.
Economic losses in sectors like agriculture, fisheries, and tourism.
Loss of potential medicines and other useful biological compounds.
Cultural impacts on communities that rely on biodiversity for their way of life.

formulas.title: Extinction Rate Calculation
formulas.formula:
E = (S/N) × 100
Where:
E = Percentage of species extinct
S = Number of species that went extinct
N = Total number of species
formulas.explanation: Measures the percentage of species that have gone extinct over a specific time period.

formulas.title: Population Viability Analysis (PVA)
formulas.formula:
P(extinction) = f(N, b, d, K, σ²)
Where:
N = Population size
b = Birth rate
d = Death rate
K = Carrying capacity
σ² = Environmental variance
formulas.explanation: Estimates the probability of a population going extinct within a given time frame.

formulas.title: Living Planet Index (LPI)
formulas.formula:
LPI = (Σ(Nt/N₀)^(1/t) - 1) × 100
Where:
Nt = Population size at time t
N₀ = Initial population size
t = Time period
formulas.explanation: Measures the average change in population size of vertebrate species over time.

realworld.title: Conservation Biology
realworld.description: Understanding extinction risks helps in developing targeted conservation programs for endangered species like the Indian Vulture and Snow Leopard.

realworld.title: Policy Making
realworld.description: Data on biodiversity loss informs the creation of policies like the Wildlife Protection Act and the establishment of protected areas.

realworld.title: Sustainable Development
realworld.description: Addressing biodiversity loss is essential for achieving the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), particularly SDG 14 (Life Below Water) and SDG 15 (Life on Land).

notes.title: In-situ Conservation
points: Conservation of species in their natural habitats.
Includes protected areas like national parks, wildlife sanctuaries, and biosphere reserves.
Example: Project Tiger and Project Elephant in India.
Advantages: Maintains natural ecosystems and evolutionary processes.
Challenges: Requires large areas and may conflict with human activities.
India has over 900 protected areas covering about 5% of the country's total area.

notes.title: Ex-situ Conservation
points: Conservation of components of biological diversity outside their natural habitats.
Includes zoos, botanical gardens, seed banks, and gene banks.
Example: National Bureau of Plant Genetic Resources (NBPGR) in India.
Cryopreservation of gametes, embryos, and tissues.
Advantages: Protects species from extinction when in-situ conservation is not possible.
Challenges: High cost and may lead to loss of genetic diversity over generations.

notes.title: Community-based Conservation
points: Involves local communities in conservation efforts.
Recognizes traditional knowledge and practices.
Example: Joint Forest Management (JFM) in India.
Sacred groves in India as traditional conservation areas.
Ecotourism as a means of generating income while conserving biodiversity.
Advantages: More sustainable as it involves stakeholders directly.

notes.title: International Agreements
points: Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD): Aims to conserve biodiversity, promote sustainable use, and ensure fair benefit-sharing.
CITES (Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species): Regulates international trade in endangered species.
Ramsar Convention: Focuses on conservation and wise use of wetlands.
India is a signatory to all major international biodiversity conventions.
National Biodiversity Action Plan (NBAP) aligns with global biodiversity targets.

formulas.title: Protected Area Coverage
formulas.formula: PA Coverage (%) = (Area of PAs / Total area of country/region) × 100
formulas.explanation: Measures the percentage of a country's or region's area that is under protection.

formulas.title: Conservation Effectiveness
formulas.formula: Effectiveness = (Post-conservation biodiversity - Pre-conservation biodiversity) / Conservation effort
formulas.explanation: Measures the change in biodiversity relative to the resources invested in conservation.

formulas.title: Metapopulation Viability
formulas.formula:
MVP = (4πN₀σ²) / (r - σ²/2)
Where:
MVP = Minimum Viable Population
N₀ = Initial population size
σ² = Variance in population growth rate
r = Intrinsic growth rate
formulas.explanation: Estimates the minimum population size required for long-term persistence.

realworld.title: Wildlife Conservation

realworld.title: Agriculture

realworld.title: Urban Planning

notes.title: Basic Concepts of Relations
points: A relation R from a set A to a set B is a subset of the Cartesian product A × B.
If (a, b) ∈ R, we say that 'a is related to b' and write a R b.
The domain of R is the set of all first elements of the ordered pairs in R.
The range of R is the set of all second elements of the ordered pairs in R.
The co-domain is the set B to which the relation maps the elements of set A.

notes.title: Types of Relations
points: Empty Relation: A relation R in a set A is called empty relation, if no element of A is related to any element of A, i.e., R = ∅ ⊂ A × A.
Universal Relation: A relation R in a set A is called universal relation, if each element of A is related to every element of A, i.e., R = A × A.
Reflexive Relation: A relation R in a set A is called reflexive, if (a, a) ∈ R, for every a ∈ A.
Symmetric Relation: A relation R in a set A is called symmetric, if (a₁, a₂) ∈ R implies that (a₂, a₁) ∈ R, for all a₁, a₂ ∈ A.
Transitive Relation: A relation R in a set A is called transitive, if (a₁, a₂) ∈ R and (a₂, a₃) ∈ R implies that (a₁, a₃) ∈ R, for all a₁, a₂, a₃ ∈ A.
Equivalence Relation: A relation R in a set A is said to be an equivalence relation if R is reflexive, symmetric and transitive.

notes.title: Equivalence Classes and Partitions
points: An equivalence relation on a set A partitions the set into disjoint equivalence classes.
The equivalence class of an element a ∈ A is the set of all elements in A that are related to a.
Two equivalence classes are either identical or disjoint.
The union of all equivalence classes gives the original set A.
The set of all equivalence classes is called the quotient set of A by R, denoted A/R.

formulas.title: Number of Relations
formulas.formula:
If set A has m elements and set B has n elements, then:
- Number of relations from A to B = 2^(m×n)
- Number of relations on A = 2^(m²)
formulas.explanation: The number of possible relations between two finite sets is determined by the number of possible subsets of their Cartesian product.

formulas.title: Equivalence Relation Properties
formulas.formula:
For a relation R on set A:
1. Reflexive: (a, a) ∈ R, ∀ a ∈ A
2. Symmetric: (a, b) ∈ R ⇒ (b, a) ∈ R, ∀ a, b ∈ A
3. Transitive: (a, b) ∈ R and (b, c) ∈ R ⇒ (a, c) ∈ R, ∀ a, b, c ∈ A
formulas.explanation: These are the three properties that define an equivalence relation on a set.

formulas.title: Equivalence Class
formulas.explanation: The equivalence class of an element a under relation R is the set of all elements in A that are related to a.

realworld.title: Social Networks
realworld.description: In social networks, the 'friendship' relation can be analyzed using relation properties. If person A is a friend of person B, this relation can be reflexive (if we consider someone to be friends with themselves), symmetric (if friendship is mutual), and might be transitive (if friends of friends are considered friends).

realworld.title: Database Management
realworld.description: In relational databases, tables represent relations between different data entities. The concepts of primary keys, foreign keys, and join operations are all based on mathematical relations and their properties.

realworld.title: Computer Science
realworld.description: In automata theory, states of a finite automaton can be related through equivalence relations, where equivalent states produce the same output for all possible input strings, leading to state minimization in finite state machines.

notes.title: Basic Concepts of Functions
points: A function f from a set A to a set B is a special type of relation where every element of A has exactly one image in B.
Notation: f: A → B where A is the domain and B is the co-domain of f.
The range of f is the set of all images of elements of A under f, i.e., {f(x) | x ∈ A}.
A function is called real-valued if its co-domain is the set of real numbers ℝ.
A function is called real function if both its domain and co-domain are subsets of ℝ.

notes.title: Types of Functions
points: One-One (Injective) Function: A function f: A → B is one-one if f(x₁) = f(x₂) ⇒ x₁ = x₂ for all x₁, x₂ ∈ A.
Onto (Surjective) Function: A function f: A → B is onto if every element of B is the image of some element of A, i.e., for every y ∈ B, there exists an x ∈ A such that f(x) = y.
Bijective Function: A function f: A → B is bijective if it is both one-one and onto.
Constant Function: A function f: A → B is called a constant function if there exists c ∈ B such that f(x) = c for all x ∈ A.
Identity Function: The function f: A → A defined by f(x) = x for all x ∈ A is called the identity function on A.
Polynomial Function: A function f: ℝ → ℝ defined by f(x) = a₀ + a₁x + a₂x² + ... + aₙxⁿ, where aₙ ≠ 0, is called a polynomial function of degree n.
Rational Function: A function of the form f(x) = p(x)/q(x), where p(x) and q(x) are polynomial functions and q(x) ≠ 0.

notes.title: Graphs of Basic Functions
points: The graph of a function f: A → B is the set of all points (x, f(x)) where x ∈ A.
The graph of a constant function f(x) = c is a horizontal line parallel to the x-axis.
The graph of the identity function f(x) = x is a straight line passing through the origin at 45° to both axes.
The graph of a quadratic function f(x) = ax² + bx + c is a parabola opening upwards if a > 0 and downwards if a < 0.
The graph of f(x) = 1/x is a hyperbola with the x and y axes as asymptotes.
The graph of f(x) = |x| is V-shaped with its vertex at the origin.

formulas.title: Function Definition
formulas.formula:
f: A → B is a function if:
1. For every a ∈ A, there exists b ∈ B such that (a, b) ∈ f.
2. If (a, b) ∈ f and (a, c) ∈ f, then b = c.
formulas.explanation: The first condition ensures that every element in the domain is mapped, and the second ensures that each element is mapped to exactly one element in the co-domain.

formulas.title: Composition of Functions
formulas.formula: If f: A → B and g: B → C are two functions, then the composition of f and g, denoted by gof: A → C, is defined as (gof)(x) = g(f(x)) for all x ∈ A.
formulas.explanation: The composition is only defined when the co-domain of f is the same as the domain of g.

formulas.title: Inverse Function
formulas.formula: If f: A → B is a bijection, then the inverse function f⁻¹: B → A is defined by f⁻¹(y) = x if and only if f(x) = y.
formulas.explanation: The inverse function exists only when the original function is bijective (both one-one and onto).

realworld.title: Physics
realworld.description: In kinematics, the position of an object is often expressed as a function of time, x(t). The derivative of this function gives the velocity v(t), and the second derivative gives the acceleration a(t). Different types of motion (constant velocity, accelerated, etc.) correspond to different types of functions.

realworld.title: Economics
realworld.description: In economics, supply and demand are represented as functions of price. The demand function typically decreases with price, while the supply function typically increases with price. The intersection point of these two functions determines the market equilibrium.

realworld.title: Computer Science
realworld.description: In computer science, hash functions map data of arbitrary size to fixed-size values. The properties of these functions (deterministic, efficient to compute, minimize collisions) are crucial for their use in data structures like hash tables and for data integrity verification.

notes.title: Definition and Basic Properties
points: Let f: A → B and g: B → C be two functions. Then the composition of f and g, denoted by gof, is the function from A to C defined by (gof)(x) = g(f(x)) for all x ∈ A.
The composition of functions is associative: If f: A → B, g: B → C, and h: C → D are three functions, then ho(gof) = (hog)of.
The composition of functions is not commutative in general: fog may not be equal to gof, and in fact, one might be defined while the other is not.
The composition of two injective functions is injective.
The composition of two surjective functions is surjective.
The composition of two bijective functions is bijective.

notes.title: Inverse of Composition
points: If f: A → B and g: B → C are both bijections, then (gof)⁻¹ = f⁻¹og⁻¹.
For any function f: A → B, if I_A and I_B are the identity functions on A and B respectively, then foI_A = f and I_Bof = f.
If f: A → B is a bijection, then f⁻¹of = I_A and fof⁻¹ = I_B.
The composition of a function with its inverse gives the identity function.
If gof is bijective, then f is injective and g is surjective.

notes.title: Composition with Special Functions
points: The composition of two linear functions f(x) = ax + b and g(x) = cx + d is gof(x) = c(ax + b) + d = acx + (bc + d), which is also a linear function.
The composition of two polynomial functions is another polynomial function.
The composition of two even functions is even, two odd functions is odd, and an even and an odd function is even.
The composition of periodic functions is periodic, and the period of the composition is the least common multiple of the individual periods.
The composition of continuous functions is continuous, and the composition of differentiable functions is differentiable (where defined).

formulas.title: Composition Definition
formulas.formula:
(gof)(x) = g(f(x))
Domain of gof = {x ∈ domain(f) | f(x) ∈ domain(g)}
formulas.explanation: The composition gof is defined when the range of f is a subset of the domain of g.

formulas.title: Inverse of Composition
formulas.formula: If f and g are bijections, then (gof)⁻¹ = f⁻¹og⁻¹
formulas.explanation: The inverse of a composition is the composition of the inverses in reverse order.

formulas.title: Composition with Identity
formulas.explanation: Composing any function with the appropriate identity function leaves the function unchanged.

realworld.title: Computer Programming
realworld.description: In functional programming, functions are often composed together to build complex operations from simpler ones. For example, in a data processing pipeline, the output of one function becomes the input to the next, creating a composition that transforms data through multiple stages.

realworld.title: Physics
realworld.description: In physics, especially in relativity and quantum mechanics, coordinate systems are often transformed. The composition of these transformations represents performing one transformation after another, which is crucial for understanding how different reference frames relate to each other.

realworld.title: Economics
realworld.description: In economics, production functions can be composed to model multi-stage production processes. For example, if f(x) represents the output from input x in the first stage, and g(y) represents the final output from intermediate good y, then gof(x) gives the final output from the initial input x.

notes.title: Definition and Basic Properties
points: A function f: X → Y is invertible if there exists a function g: Y → X such that gof = I_X and fog = I_Y, where I_X and I_Y are identity functions on X and Y respectively.
A function is invertible if and only if it is bijective (both one-one and onto).
The inverse of a function is unique and is denoted by f⁻¹.
The graph of f⁻¹ is the reflection of the graph of f about the line y = x.
The domain of f becomes the range of f⁻¹, and the range of f becomes the domain of f⁻¹.
If f and g are both bijections, then (gof)⁻¹ = f⁻¹og⁻¹.

notes.title: Finding Inverses
points:
To find the inverse of a function y = f(x):
                1. Replace f(x) with y.
                2. Swap x and y.
                3. Solve for y.
                4. Replace y with f⁻¹(x).
The inverse of a strictly increasing function is strictly increasing, and the inverse of a strictly decreasing function is strictly decreasing.
If a function is not bijective, we can often restrict its domain to make it bijective and then find its inverse.
The inverse of a linear function f(x) = ax + b is f⁻¹(x) = (x - b)/a, provided a ≠ 0.
The inverse of f(x) = x² is f⁻¹(x) = √x, but only if we restrict the domain of f to x ≥ 0.

notes.title: Inverse Trigonometric Functions
points: The inverse sine function, sin⁻¹x, has domain [-1, 1] and range [-π/2, π/2].
The inverse cosine function, cos⁻¹x, has domain [-1, 1] and range [0, π].
The inverse tangent function, tan⁻¹x, has domain ℝ and range (-π/2, π/2).
The inverse cotangent function, cot⁻¹x, has domain ℝ and range (0, π).
The inverse secant function, sec⁻¹x, has domain (-∞, -1] ∪ [1, ∞) and range [0, π/2) ∪ (π/2, π].
The inverse cosecant function, csc⁻¹x, has domain (-∞, -1] ∪ [1, ∞) and range [-π/2, 0) ∪ (0, π/2].

formulas.title: Inverse Function Definition
formulas.formula:
f⁻¹(f(x)) = x for all x in the domain of f
f(f⁻¹(y)) = y for all y in the range of f
formulas.explanation: These equations define the fundamental property of inverse functions - they 'undo' each other's actions.

formulas.title: Derivative of Inverse Function
formulas.formula:
If f is differentiable and has an inverse, then:
(f⁻¹)'(y) = 1 / f'(x), where y = f(x)
formulas.explanation: This formula relates the derivative of a function to the derivative of its inverse, which is useful in calculus.

formulas.title: Inverse of Linear Function
formulas.formula: If f(x) = ax + b, then f⁻¹(x) = (x - b)/a, a ≠ 0
formulas.explanation: The inverse of a linear function is also a linear function, with slope equal to the reciprocal of the original slope.

realworld.title: Cryptography
realworld.description: In public key cryptography, the security relies on the existence of one-way functions - functions that are easy to compute but computationally difficult to invert. The RSA algorithm, for example, is based on the difficulty of factoring the product of two large prime numbers, which is the inverse of the multiplication operation.

realworld.title: Engineering
realworld.description: In control theory, the concept of invertibility is crucial. A system is invertible if distinct inputs produce distinct outputs. The inverse system can be used to design controllers that can cancel out the effect of the original system, which is useful in feedback control systems.

realworld.title: Economics
realworld.description: In economics, while we often express quantity demanded as a function of price q = D(p), we can also express price as a function of quantity p = D⁻¹(q). The inverse demand function is particularly useful in contexts where firms choose quantities rather than prices, such as in Cournot competition models.

notes.title: Introduction to Inverse Trigonometric Functions
points: Inverse trigonometric functions are the inverse functions of the basic trigonometric functions (sine, cosine, tangent, etc.).
They are used to find the angle when the value of the trigonometric function is known.
The six inverse trigonometric functions are: arcsin(x), arccos(x), arctan(x), arccsc(x), arcsec(x), and arccot(x).
These functions are also written as sin⁻¹(x), cos⁻¹(x), tan⁻¹(x), csc⁻¹(x), sec⁻¹(x), and cot⁻¹(x).
The output of these functions is an angle, and their input is a ratio of sides of a right triangle.

notes.title: Basic Definitions
points: If y = sin⁻¹x, then x = sin y, where -1 ≤ x ≤ 1 and -π/2 ≤ y ≤ π/2.
If y = cos⁻¹x, then x = cos y, where -1 ≤ x ≤ 1 and 0 ≤ y ≤ π.
If y = tan⁻¹x, then x = tan y, where x ∈ ℝ and -π/2 < y < π/2.
If y = cot⁻¹x, then x = cot y, where x ∈ ℝ and 0 < y < π.
If y = sec⁻¹x, then x = sec y, where |x| ≥ 1 and 0 ≤ y ≤ π, y ≠ π/2.
If y = csc⁻¹x, then x = csc y, where |x| ≥ 1 and -π/2 ≤ y ≤ π/2, y ≠ 0.

notes.title: Graphs of Inverse Trigonometric Functions
points: The graph of y = sin⁻¹x is strictly increasing and passes through the origin.
The graph of y = cos⁻¹x is strictly decreasing and passes through (0, π/2).
The graph of y = tan⁻¹x has horizontal asymptotes at y = ±π/2.
The graphs of inverse trigonometric functions are reflections of the corresponding trigonometric functions about the line y = x, but only in their principal value branches.
The domain and range of these functions are restricted to make them one-to-one and hence invertible.

formulas.title: Basic Inverse Trigonometric Functions
formulas.formula: y = sin⁻¹x ⇔ x = sin y, where x ∈ [-1, 1] and y ∈ [-π/2, π/2]
formulas.explanation: Defines the inverse sine function, which gives the angle whose sine is x.

formulas.title: Range of Inverse Functions
formulas.formula:
Range of sin⁻¹x = [-π/2, π/2]
Range of cos⁻¹x = [0, π]
Range of tan⁻¹x = (-π/2, π/2)
formulas.explanation: The range is restricted to ensure the functions are one-to-one and therefore invertible.

formulas.explanation: These identities show how inverse trigonometric functions behave with negative inputs.

realworld.title: Engineering
realworld.description: Inverse trigonometric functions are used to calculate angles in various engineering applications, such as determining the angle of elevation or depression in surveying.

realworld.title: Physics
realworld.description: Used to calculate the angle of projection when the range and height of a projectile are known.

realworld.title: Computer Graphics
realworld.description: Inverse trigonometric functions help in determining rotation angles when working with 2D and 3D graphics.

notes.title: Domain and Range of Inverse Trigonometric Functions
points: For sin⁻¹x: Domain = [-1, 1], Range = [-π/2, π/2].
For cos⁻¹x: Domain = [-1, 1], Range = [0, π].
For tan⁻¹x: Domain = ℝ, Range = (-π/2, π/2).
For cot⁻¹x: Domain = ℝ, Range = (0, π).
For sec⁻¹x: Domain = (-∞, -1] ∪ [1, ∞), Range = [0, π] - {π/2}.
For csc⁻¹x: Domain = (-∞, -1] ∪ [1, ∞), Range = [-π/2, π/2] - {0}.
The domains are restricted to make the functions one-to-one.
The ranges are chosen to be continuous and as large as possible while maintaining the function's one-to-one nature.

notes.title: Important Observations
points: The domain of inverse trigonometric functions is the range of the corresponding trigonometric functions.
The range of inverse trigonometric functions is the domain of the corresponding trigonometric functions, but restricted to make them one-to-one.
The graphs of inverse trigonometric functions are symmetric about the origin or y-axis based on their odd/even nature.
sin⁻¹x and tan⁻¹x are odd functions, while cos⁻¹x is neither even nor odd.
The composition of a trigonometric function with its inverse (and vice versa) has specific domain restrictions to maintain the principal value.

formulas.title: Domain and Range Summary
formulas.explanation: Table showing the domain and range of the three primary inverse trigonometric functions.

formulas.title: Composition with Trigonometric Functions
formulas.formula:
sin⁻¹(sin θ) = θ, for θ ∈ [-π/2, π/2]
cos⁻¹(cos θ) = θ, for θ ∈ [0, π]
tan⁻¹(tan θ) = θ, for θ ∈ (-π/2, π/2)
formulas.explanation: These identities hold only when θ is in the principal value range of the respective inverse function.

formulas.title: Range Addition Formulas
formulas.formula:
tan⁻¹x + tan⁻¹y = tan⁻¹((x+y)/(1-xy)), if xy < 1
tan⁻¹x - tan⁻¹y = tan⁻¹((x-y)/(1+xy)), if xy > -1
formulas.explanation: Formulas for the sum and difference of two arctangent functions, with conditions to ensure the result stays within the principal value range.

realworld.title: Navigation
realworld.description: In navigation, inverse trigonometric functions help calculate the bearing between two points when their coordinates are known, with careful consideration of the domain and range to ensure correct angle calculation.

realworld.title: Robotics
realworld.description: Inverse kinematics in robotics uses inverse trigonometric functions to determine joint angles needed to position a robot's end effector at a specific location, with domain restrictions ensuring physically possible solutions.

realworld.title: Architecture
realworld.description: Architects use inverse trigonometric functions to determine the angle of a roof pitch based on the rise and run, where the domain and range ensure the angle is within practical building limits.

notes.title: Understanding Principal Value Branches
points: Since trigonometric functions are periodic, they are not one-to-one over their entire domain. To define their inverses, we restrict their domains to principal value branches.
The principal value branch is the range of the inverse function that contains the smallest non-negative angle.
For sin⁻¹x: The principal value branch is [-π/2, π/2].
For cos⁻¹x: The principal value branch is [0, π].
For tan⁻¹x: The principal value branch is (-π/2, π/2).
For cot⁻¹x: The principal value branch is (0, π).
For sec⁻¹x: The principal value branch is [0, π] - {π/2}.
For csc⁻¹x: The principal value branch is [-π/2, π/2] - {0}.

notes.title: Properties of Principal Values
points: The principal value is always the smallest non-negative angle (or the angle closest to zero).
For negative arguments, the principal value is negative for odd functions (sin⁻¹, tan⁻¹, csc⁻¹, cot⁻¹).
The choice of principal value branch ensures that the inverse functions are continuous and differentiable.
Different branches are used in different contexts, but the principal value branch is the most commonly used.
The principal value branch is sometimes called the 'main branch' of the inverse trigonometric function.

notes.title: Multiple Solutions and General Solutions
points: The equation sin θ = k has infinitely many solutions: θ = nπ + (-1)ⁿα, where α is the principal value and n is any integer.
The equation cos θ = k has solutions: θ = 2nπ ± α, where α is the principal value.
The equation tan θ = k has solutions: θ = nπ + α, where α is the principal value.
These general solutions are important in solving trigonometric equations where all possible solutions are required.
The principal value is used as the reference angle to find all other solutions.

---------|-------------------

tan⁻¹x  | (-π/2, π/2)

csc⁻¹x  | [-π/2, π/2] - {0}

If sin θ = k, then θ = nπ + (-1)ⁿα, where α = sin⁻¹k

If tan θ = k, then θ = nπ + α, where α = tan⁻¹k
formulas.explanation: General solutions for basic trigonometric equations, where n is any integer and α is the principal value.

formulas.title: Principal Value for Negative Arguments
formulas.explanation: These formulas show how principal values are determined for negative arguments, maintaining the function's range.

realworld.title: Signal Processing
realworld.description: In signal processing, the principal value of the phase angle is often used to represent periodic signals, ensuring the phase is within a standard range (typically -π to π or 0 to 2π).

realworld.title: Navigation Systems
realworld.description: Navigation systems use principal values to standardize bearing angles, typically between 0° and 360° or -180° to 180°, to avoid ambiguity in direction calculations.

realworld.title: Robotics
realworld.description: In robotic arm control, principal value branches ensure that joint angles remain within their physical limits, preventing damage to the mechanism and ensuring predictable movement.

points: sin⁻¹(sin θ) = θ, for θ ∈ [-π/2, π/2].
cos⁻¹(cos θ) = θ, for θ ∈ [0, π].
tan⁻¹(tan θ) = θ, for θ ∈ (-π/2, π/2).
sin(sin⁻¹x) = x, for x ∈ [-1, 1].
cos(cos⁻¹x) = x, for x ∈ [-1, 1].
tan(tan⁻¹x) = x, for all real x.
sin⁻¹x + cos⁻¹x = π/2, for x ∈ [-1, 1].
tan⁻¹x + cot⁻¹x = π/2, for all real x.
sec⁻¹x + csc⁻¹x = π/2, for |x| ≥ 1.

notes.title: Sum and Difference Formulas
points: sin⁻¹x + sin⁻¹y = sin⁻¹(x√(1-y²) + y√(1-x²)), if x² + y² ≤ 1 or xy ≤ 0.
sin⁻¹x - sin⁻¹y = sin⁻¹(x√(1-y²) - y√(1-x²)), if x² + y² ≤ 1 or xy ≥ 0.
cos⁻¹x + cos⁻¹y = cos⁻¹(xy - √(1-x²)√(1-y²)), if x + y ≥ 0.
cos⁻¹x - cos⁻¹y = -cos⁻¹(xy + √(1-x²)√(1-y²)), if x ≤ y.
tan⁻¹x + tan⁻¹y = tan⁻¹((x+y)/(1-xy)), if xy < 1.
tan⁻¹x - tan⁻¹y = tan⁻¹((x-y)/(1+xy)), if xy > -1.
If xy > 1 and x, y > 0, then tan⁻¹x + tan⁻¹y = π + tan⁻¹((x+y)/(1-xy)).

notes.title: Multiple Angle and Conversion Formulas
points: 2tan⁻¹x = sin⁻¹(2x/(1+x²)), for |x| ≤ 1.
2tan⁻¹x = cos⁻¹((1-x²)/(1+x²)), for x ≥ 0.
2tan⁻¹x = tan⁻¹(2x/(1-x²)), for |x| < 1.
sin⁻¹(2x√(1-x²)) = 2sin⁻¹x, for |x| ≤ 1/√2.
sin⁻¹(2x√(1-x²)) = 2cos⁻¹x, for 1/√2 ≤ x ≤ 1.
cos⁻¹(2x²-1) = 2cos⁻¹x, for 0 ≤ x ≤ 1.
cos⁻¹(2x²-1) = 2sin⁻¹x, for -1 ≤ x ≤ 0.
tan⁻¹x + tan⁻¹(1/x) = π/2, for x > 0.
tan⁻¹x + tan⁻¹(1/x) = -π/2, for x < 0.

formulas.title: Sum of Arctangents
formulas.formula:
tan⁻¹x + tan⁻¹y = tan⁻¹((x+y)/(1-xy)), if xy < 1
= π + tan⁻¹((x+y)/(1-xy)), if x, y > 0 and xy > 1
= -π + tan⁻¹((x+y)/(1-xy)), if x, y < 0 and xy > 1
formulas.explanation: The sum of two arctangent functions, with different cases based on the values of x and y to ensure the result stays within the principal value range.

formulas.explanation: Triple angle formulas for inverse trigonometric functions, with their respective domain restrictions.

notes.title: Basic Matrix Concepts
points: A matrix is a rectangular array of numbers, symbols, or expressions arranged in rows and columns.
Order of a matrix is given by m × n, where m is the number of rows and n is the number of columns.
Elements of a matrix are denoted by aᵢⱼ, where i is the row number and j is the column number.
Row matrix: A matrix with only one row. Example: [1 2 3]
Column matrix: A matrix with only one column. Example: [1; 2; 3]

notes.title: Special Types of Matrices
points: Square matrix: Number of rows equals number of columns (m = n).
Diagonal matrix: A square matrix where all non-diagonal elements are zero.
Scalar matrix: A diagonal matrix with all diagonal elements equal.
Identity matrix (I): A scalar matrix with diagonal elements equal to 1.
Null/Zero matrix: All elements are zero.
Upper triangular matrix: All elements below the main diagonal are zero.
Lower triangular matrix: All elements above the main diagonal are zero.

notes.title: Equality of Matrices
points: Two matrices A and B are equal if they have the same order and their corresponding elements are equal.
If A = [aᵢⱼ] and B = [bᵢⱼ], then A = B if and only if aᵢⱼ = bᵢⱼ for all i and j.
Equal matrices must have the same dimensions.

formulas.title: General Matrix
formulas.explanation: A matrix A of order m×n with elements aᵢⱼ where i = 1,2,...,m and j = 1,2,...,n.

formulas.title: Identity Matrix
formulas.formula: I = [δᵢⱼ] where δᵢⱼ = 1 if i = j, else 0
formulas.explanation: A square matrix with 1s on the main diagonal and 0s elsewhere.

formulas.title: Diagonal Matrix
formulas.explanation: A square matrix where all non-diagonal elements are zero and diagonal elements are d₁, d₂, ..., dₙ.

notes.title: Matrix Addition and Subtraction
points: Matrices can be added or subtracted if they have the same order.
If A = [aᵢⱼ] and B = [bᵢⱼ], then A ± B = [aᵢⱼ ± bᵢⱼ].
Properties: Commutative (A+B = B+A), Associative (A+(B+C) = (A+B)+C).
Additive identity: A + 0 = A, where 0 is the null matrix of same order.
Additive inverse: For matrix A, there exists -A such that A + (-A) = 0.

notes.title: Scalar Multiplication
points: If k is a scalar and A = [aᵢⱼ], then kA = [kaᵢⱼ].
Properties: k(A+B) = kA + kB, (k₁+k₂)A = k₁A + k₂A, k₁(k₂A) = (k₁k₂)A.
-A = (-1)A is the additive inverse of A.
0A = 0 (the zero matrix).

notes.title: Matrix Multiplication
points: For A_{m×n} and B_{n×p}, the product AB is defined and has order m×p.
Element cᵢⱼ of AB is the dot product of iᵗʰ row of A and jᵗʰ column of B.
Properties: Associative (AB)C = A(BC), Distributive over addition A(B+C) = AB + AC.
Not commutative in general (AB ≠ BA).
AI = IA = A, where I is the identity matrix of appropriate order.

notes.title: Properties of Matrix Operations
points: A(BC) = (AB)C (Associative for multiplication).
A(B + C) = AB + AC and (A + B)C = AC + BC (Distributive properties).
k(AB) = (kA)B = A(kB) for any scalar k.
Matrix multiplication is not commutative: AB ≠ BA in general.
AB = 0 does not necessarily imply A = 0 or B = 0.

formulas.title: Matrix Addition
formulas.formula: [a b; c d] + [e f; g h] = [a+e b+f; c+g d+h]
formulas.explanation: Add corresponding elements of the matrices.

formulas.title: Matrix Multiplication
formulas.formula: [a b; c d] × [e f; g h] = [ae+bg af+bh; ce+dg cf+dh]
formulas.explanation: Element cᵢⱼ is the dot product of row i of first matrix and column j of second matrix.

formulas.title: Scalar Multiplication
formulas.formula: k × [a b; c d] = [ka kb; kc kd]
formulas.explanation: Multiply each element of the matrix by the scalar k.

notes.title: Definition and Properties
points: The transpose of a matrix A, denoted by Aᵀ or A', is obtained by interchanging rows and columns.
If A is of order m×n, then Aᵀ is of order n×m.
(Aᵀ)ᵀ = A
(A + B)ᵀ = Aᵀ + Bᵀ
(kA)ᵀ = kAᵀ for any scalar k
(AB)ᵀ = BᵀAᵀ (Reversing the order of multiplication)
For a square matrix A, if A = Aᵀ, then A is called a symmetric matrix.
For a square matrix A, if A = -Aᵀ, then A is called a skew-symmetric matrix.

notes.title: Symmetric and Skew-Symmetric Matrices
points: A square matrix A is symmetric if A = Aᵀ.
A square matrix A is skew-symmetric if A = -Aᵀ.
For a skew-symmetric matrix, the diagonal elements must be zero.
Any square matrix can be expressed as the sum of a symmetric and a skew-symmetric matrix: A = ½(A + Aᵀ) + ½(A - Aᵀ).

formulas.title: Transpose of a Matrix
formulas.explanation: The element at position (i,j) in A moves to position (j,i) in Aᵀ.

formulas.title: Transpose of Product
formulas.explanation: The transpose of a product is the product of transposes in reverse order.

formulas.title: Symmetric Matrix
formulas.formula: A is symmetric if A = Aᵀ
formulas.explanation: The matrix is equal to its transpose, meaning aᵢⱼ = aⱼᵢ for all i,j.

formulas.title: Skew-Symmetric Matrix
formulas.explanation: The matrix equals the negative of its transpose, with aᵢⱼ = -aⱼᵢ and aᵢᵢ = 0.

notes.title: Symmetric Matrices
points: A square matrix A is symmetric if A = Aᵀ.
The elements are symmetric about the main diagonal: aᵢⱼ = aⱼᵢ.
The sum of two symmetric matrices is symmetric.
If A is invertible and symmetric, then A⁻¹ is also symmetric.
For any matrix A, both AAᵀ and AᵀA are symmetric matrices.
Eigenvalues of a real symmetric matrix are always real.
Eigenvectors corresponding to distinct eigenvalues of a symmetric matrix are orthogonal.

notes.title: Skew-Symmetric Matrices
points: A square matrix A is skew-symmetric if A = -Aᵀ.
All diagonal elements of a skew-symmetric matrix are zero: aᵢᵢ = 0.
The elements satisfy aᵢⱼ = -aⱼᵢ for i ≠ j.
The sum of two skew-symmetric matrices is skew-symmetric.
For any square matrix A, the matrix (A - Aᵀ) is always skew-symmetric.
The eigenvalues of a real skew-symmetric matrix are either zero or purely imaginary.
The determinant of a skew-symmetric matrix of odd order is zero.

notes.title: Properties and Theorems
points: Any real square matrix can be uniquely expressed as the sum of a symmetric and a skew-symmetric matrix: A = ½(A + Aᵀ) + ½(A - Aᵀ).
The product of two symmetric matrices is symmetric if and only if the matrices commute (AB = BA).
If A is a square matrix, then A + Aᵀ is symmetric and A - Aᵀ is skew-symmetric.
The inverse of a symmetric matrix (if it exists) is symmetric.
The rank of a skew-symmetric matrix is always even.

formulas.title: Symmetric Matrix
formulas.explanation: A square matrix equal to its transpose, with aᵢⱼ = aⱼᵢ for all i,j.

formulas.title: Skew-Symmetric Matrix

notes.title: Elementary Row Operations
points: Type I: Interchange any two rows. Notation: Rᵢ ↔ Rⱼ
Type II: Multiply a row by a non-zero scalar. Notation: Rᵢ → kRᵢ
Type III: Add a multiple of one row to another row. Notation: Rᵢ → Rᵢ + kRⱼ
These operations are used to solve systems of linear equations and find matrix inverses.
Each elementary row operation can be represented by an elementary matrix.

notes.title: Elementary Column Operations
points: Type I: Interchange any two columns. Notation: Cᵢ ↔ Cⱼ
Type II: Multiply a column by a non-zero scalar. Notation: Cᵢ → kCᵢ
Type III: Add a multiple of one column to another column. Notation: Cᵢ → Cᵢ + kCⱼ
Column operations are less commonly used than row operations but are important in certain applications.
Column operations affect the column space of a matrix but not its row space.

notes.title: Elementary Matrices
points: An elementary matrix is obtained by performing a single elementary row operation on an identity matrix.
Multiplying a matrix A on the left by an elementary matrix performs the corresponding row operation on A.
Multiplying on the right by an elementary matrix performs the corresponding column operation.
Elementary matrices are invertible, and their inverses are also elementary matrices.
Any invertible matrix can be expressed as a product of elementary matrices.

notes.title: Row Echelon Form (REF) and Reduced Row Echelon Form (RREF)
points: A matrix is in row echelon form (REF) if all zero rows are at the bottom, the leading coefficient of a non-zero row is always to the right of the leading coefficient of the row above it, and all entries below a leading coefficient are zero.
A matrix is in reduced row echelon form (RREF) if it's in REF, the leading coefficient of each non-zero row is 1, and each leading 1 is the only non-zero entry in its column.
Every matrix can be transformed to REF and RREF using elementary row operations.
The RREF of a matrix is unique.
RREF is used to solve systems of linear equations and find matrix inverses.

formulas.title: Elementary Matrix for Row Swap
formulas.formula: E = I - eᵢeᵢᵀ - eⱼeⱼᵀ + eᵢeⱼᵀ + eⱼeᵢᵀ
formulas.explanation: Elementary matrix that swaps rows i and j when multiplied on the left of a matrix.

formulas.title: Elementary Matrix for Row Addition
formulas.explanation: Elementary matrix that adds k times row j to row i when multiplied on the left of a matrix.

notes.title: Introduction to Determinants
points: A determinant is a scalar value that can be computed from the elements of a square matrix.
Denoted by |A| or det(A) for matrix A.
For a 2×2 matrix A = [a b; c d], |A| = ad - bc.
For a 3×3 matrix, the determinant can be calculated using the rule of Sarrus or expansion by minors.
Determinant exists only for square matrices.

notes.title: Expansion of Determinants
points: For a 2×2 matrix: |A| = a₁₁a₂₂ - a₁₂a₂₁
For a 3×3 matrix: |A| = a₁₁(a₂₂a₃₃ - a₂₃a₃₂) - a₁₂(a₂₁a₃₃ - a₂₃a₃₁) + a₁₃(a₂₁a₃₂ - a₂₂a₃₁)
The sign pattern for expansion follows (-1)^(i+j) where i and j are row and column indices.
Can be expanded along any row or column using cofactors.

formulas.title: 2×2 Determinant
formulas.explanation: For any 2×2 matrix, the determinant is the product of the main diagonal minus the product of the other diagonal.

formulas.title: 3×3 Determinant (Sarrus' Rule)
formulas.formula: |A| = a(ei - fh) - b(di - fg) + c(dh - eg)
formulas.explanation: For matrix [a b c; d e f; g h i], the determinant is calculated by adding the products of the three diagonals from upper left to lower right and subtracting the products of the three diagonals from lower left to upper right.

realworld.title: System of Equations

notes.title: Basic Properties
points: |A| = |Aᵀ| (Determinant of a matrix equals the determinant of its transpose).
If any two rows or columns are identical, then |A| = 0.
If any row or column has all zeros, then |A| = 0.
If any row or column is a linear combination of other rows or columns, then |A| = 0.
|AB| = |A|·|B| for any two square matrices A and B of same order.

notes.title: Row and Column Operations
points: If two rows or columns are interchanged, the sign of the determinant changes.
Multiplying a row or column by a scalar k multiplies the determinant by k.
Adding a multiple of one row to another row does not change the value of the determinant.
If a row or column is multiplied by k and added to another row or column, the value of determinant remains unchanged.

notes.title: Special Cases
points: For a diagonal or triangular matrix, the determinant is the product of the diagonal elements.
If A is invertible, then |A⁻¹| = 1/|A|.
For any scalar k, |kA| = kⁿ|A| where n is the order of the square matrix A.
|A⁻¹| = 1/|A|, provided |A| ≠ 0.

formulas.title: Product of Determinants
formulas.explanation: The determinant of the product of two square matrices is equal to the product of their determinants.

formulas.title: Determinant of Inverse
formulas.explanation: The determinant of the inverse of a matrix is the reciprocal of the determinant of the original matrix.

formulas.title: Determinant of Transpose
formulas.explanation: The determinant of a matrix equals the determinant of its transpose.

notes.title: Minors of a Matrix
points: The minor of an element aᵢⱼ is the determinant of the submatrix obtained by deleting the iᵗʰ row and jᵗʰ column.
Denoted by Mᵢⱼ.
For a 3×3 matrix, there are 9 minors, each being a 2×2 determinant.
The minor is always associated with a specific element of the matrix.

notes.title: Cofactors of a Matrix
points: The cofactor Cᵢⱼ of element aᵢⱼ is given by (-1)ⁱ⁺ʲ × Mᵢⱼ.
The sign of the cofactor follows a checkerboard pattern starting with + in the top-left corner.
Cofactor matrix is the matrix of cofactors of corresponding elements.
Used in finding the adjoint and inverse of a matrix.

notes.title: Adjoint of a Matrix
points: The adjoint of a square matrix is the transpose of its cofactor matrix.
Denoted as adj(A).
For a 2×2 matrix [a b; c d], adj(A) = [d -b; -c a].
A·adj(A) = adj(A)·A = |A|I, where I is the identity matrix.

formulas.title: Cofactor Formula
formulas.explanation: The cofactor of an element is the minor of that element multiplied by (-1) raised to the power of the sum of its row and column indices.

formulas.title: Determinant using Cofactors
formulas.formula: |A| = Σ(aᵢⱼ × Cᵢⱼ) for any row i or column j
formulas.explanation: The determinant can be calculated by expanding along any row or column using the elements and their corresponding cofactors.

formulas.title: Adjoint Formula
formulas.explanation: The adjoint is the transpose of the cofactor matrix [Cᵢⱼ].

notes.title: Adjoint of a Matrix
points: The adjoint of a square matrix A is the transpose of its cofactor matrix.
Denoted as adj(A).
For a 2×2 matrix [a b; c d], adj(A) = [d -b; -c a].
Property: A·adj(A) = adj(A)·A = |A|I, where I is the identity matrix.
If |A| ≠ 0, then A⁻¹ = (1/|A|)·adj(A).

notes.title: Inverse of a Matrix
points: A square matrix A is invertible (non-singular) if there exists a matrix B such that AB = BA = I.
B is called the inverse of A, denoted as A⁻¹.
A matrix is invertible if and only if its determinant is non-zero.
For a 2×2 matrix [a b; c d], A⁻¹ = (1/|A|)[d -b; -c a].
(AB)⁻¹ = B⁻¹A⁻¹, provided A and B are invertible.

notes.title: Properties of Inverse
points: (A⁻¹)⁻¹ = A
(Aᵀ)⁻¹ = (A⁻¹)ᵀ
(kA)⁻¹ = (1/k)A⁻¹ for any non-zero scalar k
The inverse of a diagonal matrix is the diagonal matrix of reciprocals of the diagonal elements.

formulas.title: Inverse using Adjoint
formulas.explanation: The inverse of a non-singular matrix is equal to its adjoint divided by its determinant.

formulas.title: Inverse of 2×2 Matrix
formulas.formula: If A = [a b; c d], then A⁻¹ = (1/|A|)[d -b; -c a]
formulas.explanation: For a 2×2 matrix, swap the diagonal elements, negate the off-diagonal elements, and divide by the determinant.

formulas.title: Inverse of Product
formulas.explanation: The inverse of a product of matrices is the product of their inverses in reverse order.

notes.title: Solving Linear Equations
points: Cramer's Rule: For a system AX = B, if |A| ≠ 0, then xᵢ = |Aᵢ|/|A|, where Aᵢ is obtained by replacing the iᵗʰ column of A with B.
Applicable only when the number of equations equals the number of variables and |A| ≠ 0.
Useful for solving small systems of equations.
Inefficient for large systems compared to elimination methods.

points: A system AX = B has a unique solution if |A| ≠ 0.
If |A| = 0 and (adj A)B ≠ 0, the system is inconsistent (no solution).
If |A| = 0 and (adj A)B = 0, the system has infinitely many solutions.
For homogeneous systems (B=0), if |A| ≠ 0, the only solution is the trivial solution (X=0).

points: The characteristic equation |A - λI| = 0 is used to find eigenvalues.

notes.title: Understanding Continuity
points: A function f(x) is continuous at a point x = a if: 1) f(a) exists, 2) lim_(x→a) f(x) exists, and 3) lim_(x→a) f(x) = f(a).
If any of these conditions fail, the function is discontinuous at x = a.
A function is continuous on an interval if it is continuous at every point in that interval.
Types of discontinuities: Removable (point), Jump, and Infinite discontinuities.

notes.title: Properties of Continuous Functions
points: If f and g are continuous at a point a, then f±g, f·g, and f/g (g(a)≠0) are also continuous at a.
All polynomial functions are continuous everywhere (for all real numbers).
Rational functions are continuous at every point in their domain.
The composition of continuous functions is continuous.

notes.title: Intermediate Value Theorem
points: If f is continuous on [a,b] and k is any number between f(a) and f(b), then there exists at least one c in (a,b) such that f(c) = k.
This theorem is useful for proving the existence of roots of equations.
It guarantees that a continuous function takes on every value between f(a) and f(b) as x goes from a to b.

formulas.title: Definition of Continuity
formulas.formula:
A function f is continuous at x = a if:
1. f(a) exists
2. lim_(x→a) f(x) exists
3. lim_(x→a) f(x) = f(a)
formulas.explanation: All three conditions must be satisfied for continuity at a point

notes.title: Definition of Differentiability
points: A function f is differentiable at a point x = a if f'(a) = lim_(h→0) [f(a+h) - f(a)]/h exists.
If f is differentiable at a point, it must be continuous at that point. However, continuity does not imply differentiability.
Geometrically, differentiability means the function has a non-vertical tangent line at that point.
A function is differentiable on an interval if it is differentiable at every point in that interval.

notes.title: Non-Differentiable Cases
points: Corner points: Where the function has a sharp turn (e.g., f(x) = |x| at x=0).
Cusps: Points where the function has a vertical tangent (e.g., f(x) = x^(2/3) at x=0).
Discontinuities: Any point where the function is not continuous is not differentiable.
Vertical tangents: Where the slope becomes infinite (e.g., f(x) = x^(1/3) at x=0).

notes.title: Relation with Continuity
points: Differentiability implies continuity: If f is differentiable at a point, it must be continuous there.
Continuity does not imply differentiability: A function can be continuous at a point but not differentiable there (e.g., |x| at x=0).
A function can fail to be differentiable at points where it is not continuous.
For a function to be differentiable at a point, the left-hand and right-hand derivatives must exist and be equal.

notes.title: Understanding Composite Functions
points: A composite function is formed when one function is applied to the result of another function.
Notation: (f∘g)(x) = f(g(x)) means 'f of g of x'.
The domain of f∘g is the set of all x in the domain of g such that g(x) is in the domain of f.
Examples: sin(x²), e^(cosx), ln(2x+1) are all composite functions.

notes.title: Differentiation of Composites
points: The derivative of a composite function f(g(x)) is f'(g(x))·g'(x). This is the Chain Rule.
For multiple compositions: d/dx [f(g(h(x)))] = f'(g(h(x)))·g'(h(x))·h'(x).
The general power rule: d/dx [uⁿ] = n·u^(n-1)·du/dx, where u is a function of x.
It's often helpful to identify the 'inside' and 'outside' functions when applying the chain rule.

notes.title: Examples and Applications
points: Example: d/dx [sin(x²)] = cos(x²)·2x
Example: d/dx [e^(3x+1)] = e^(3x+1)·3
These derivatives are essential in physics for related rates problems and in economics for marginal analysis.

notes.title: Understanding the Chain Rule
points: The chain rule is used to find the derivative of composite functions.
If y = f(u) and u = g(x), then dy/dx = (dy/du)·(du/dx).
The chain rule can be extended to any number of composed functions.
It's often helpful to identify the 'inner' and 'outer' functions before applying the chain rule.

notes.title: Applications and Examples
points: Example: Find dy/dx if y = (3x² + 2x)^4. Let u = 3x² + 2x, then y = u⁴. So dy/dx = 4u³·(6x + 2) = 4(3x² + 2x)³(6x + 2).
Example: d/dx [sin(lnx)] = cos(lnx)·(1/x).
The chain rule is essential for implicit differentiation, where y is defined implicitly as a function of x.
It's also used in related rates problems where multiple quantities change with respect to time.

notes.title: Common Chain Rule Patterns

d/dx [tan(u)] = sec²(u)·du/dx

notes.title: Basic Derivatives
points: d/dx [sin⁻¹x] = 1/√(1-x²), for -1 < x < 1

d/dx [csc⁻¹x] = -1/(|x|√(x²-1)), for |x| > 1

notes.title: Chain Rule Applications
points: For a differentiable function u of x, the derivatives become:
d/dx [sin⁻¹u] = (1/√(1-u²))·du/dx

d/dx [tan⁻¹u] = (1/(1+u²))·du/dx
These are particularly useful in integration by substitution and solving differential equations.

Example: d/dx [tan⁻¹(lnx)] = (1/x)/(1+(lnx)²) = 1/[x(1+(lnx)²)]

notes.title: Understanding Rates of Change
points: The derivative dy/dx represents the rate of change of y with respect to x.
If y = f(x), then dy/dx at x = a gives the instantaneous rate of change of y with respect to x at x = a.
For motion along a straight line, if s = f(t) gives position at time t, then ds/dt gives velocity.
The second derivative d²s/dt² gives acceleration, the rate of change of velocity with respect to time.

notes.title: Related Rates
points: In related rates problems, we find the rate at which one quantity changes by relating it to other quantities whose rates of change are known.
General approach: Identify all given and required rates, find an equation relating the variables, differentiate with respect to time, and solve for the unknown rate.
Common applications include: filling/emptying containers, sliding ladders, expanding circles, and moving objects.
Always include units in the final answer and interpret the sign (positive for increasing, negative for decreasing).

notes.title: First Derivative Test
points: A function f is increasing on an interval if f'(x) > 0 for all x in that interval.
A function f is decreasing on an interval if f'(x) < 0 for all x in that interval.
Critical points occur where f'(x) = 0 or f'(x) is undefined.
The first derivative test can be used to classify critical points as local maxima, local minima, or neither.

notes.title: Monotonicity
points: A function is strictly increasing if f'(x) > 0 for all x in an interval.
A function is strictly decreasing if f'(x) < 0 for all x in an interval.
If f'(x) = 0 for all x in an interval, then f is constant on that interval.
The intervals of increase and decrease can be determined by testing points in the intervals between critical points.

formulas.title: First Derivative Test for Increasing/Decreasing
formulas.formula:

If f'(x) < 0 on (a,b), then f is decreasing on [a,b]
formulas.explanation: Determining intervals of increase and decrease using the first derivative

formulas.title: First Derivative Test for Extrema
formulas.formula:

formulas.explanation: Classifying critical points using the first derivative test

notes.title: Critical Points and Extrema
points: A critical point occurs where f'(x) = 0 or f'(x) is undefined.
A function f has a local maximum at c if f(c) ≥ f(x) for all x in some open interval containing c.
A function f has a local minimum at c if f(c) ≤ f(x) for all x in some open interval containing c.
The absolute maximum/minimum of a continuous function on a closed interval [a,b] occurs at either a critical point or at an endpoint.

notes.title: Second Derivative Test
points: If f'(c) = 0 and f''(c) > 0, then f has a local minimum at c.
If f'(c) = 0 and f''(c) < 0, then f has a local maximum at c.
If f''(c) = 0, the test is inconclusive (could be a maximum, minimum, or neither).
The second derivative also gives information about concavity: f''(x) > 0 means concave up, f''(x) < 0 means concave down.

formulas.title: Critical Points

3. The largest value is the absolute maximum, the smallest is the absolute minimum
formulas.explanation: Finding absolute extrema on a closed interval

notes.title: Equations of Tangents and Normals
points: The tangent to the curve y = f(x) at (x₀, y₀) has slope f'(x₀).
Equation of tangent: y - y₀ = f'(x₀)(x - x₀).
The normal is perpendicular to the tangent at the point of contact.
If the tangent has slope m, the normal has slope -1/m (if m ≠ 0).

notes.title: Angle Between Two Curves
points: The angle between two curves at a point of intersection is the angle between their tangents at that point.
If m₁ and m₂ are the slopes of the two tangents, then tanθ = |(m₁ - m₂)/(1 + m₁m₂)|.
Two curves are orthogonal if the product of their slopes is -1 at the point of intersection.
The condition for orthogonality of two curves y = f(x) and y = g(x) is f'(x)g'(x) = -1.

notes.title: Introduction to Integration
points: Integration is the reverse process of differentiation, also called anti-differentiation.
If d/dx[F(x)] = f(x), then ∫f(x)dx = F(x) + C, where C is the constant of integration.
The symbol ∫ is called the integral sign, f(x) is the integrand, and dx indicates integration with respect to x.
Basic integration formulas include: ∫xⁿ dx = x^(n+1)/(n+1) + C (n ≠ -1), ∫eˣ dx = eˣ + C, ∫(1/x) dx = ln|x| + C

notes.title: Integration by Substitution
points: Also known as the reverse chain rule or change of variable method.

The integral becomes ∫f(u)du which is easier to solve.
Example: ∫2x cos(x²)dx, let u = x², du = 2xdx → ∫cos(u)du = sin(u) + C = sin(x²) + C

notes.title: Integration by Parts
points: Based on the product rule of differentiation: ∫u dv = uv - ∫v du.
Choose u and dv such that the integral on the right is simpler.
LIATE rule helps in choosing u: Logarithmic, Inverse trigonometric, Algebraic, Trigonometric, Exponential.
Example: ∫x eˣ dx, let u = x, dv = eˣdx → du = dx, v = eˣ → ∫x eˣ dx = x eˣ - ∫eˣ dx = x eˣ - eˣ + C

notes.title: Partial Fractions
points: Used to integrate rational functions (P(x)/Q(x)) where degree of P < degree of Q.
Factorize the denominator Q(x) into linear and/or irreducible quadratic factors.
Express the integrand as a sum of simpler fractions with unknown coefficients.
Solve for the coefficients and integrate each term separately.

notes.title: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
points: If F(x) is an antiderivative of f(x) on [a,b], then ∫ₐᵇ f(x)dx = F(b) - F(a).
The definite integral represents the signed area under the curve y = f(x) from x = a to x = b.
If f(x) ≥ 0 on [a,b], the definite integral gives the area between the curve and the x-axis.
If f(x) takes both positive and negative values, the integral gives the net signed area.

notes.title: Evaluation of Definite Integrals
points: Find the indefinite integral (antiderivative) of the integrand.
Evaluate the antiderivative at the upper limit of integration.
Evaluate the antiderivative at the lower limit of integration.
Subtract the lower limit evaluation from the upper limit evaluation.
Example: ∫₀¹ x² dx = [x³/3]₀¹ = (1/3) - 0 = 1/3

points: ∫ₐᵇ f(x)dx = -∫ₐᵇ f(x)dx (Reversing limits changes the sign).

2. ∫ₐᵇ f(x)dx = ∫ₐᶜ f(x)dx + ∫_c^b f(x)dx
3. ∫ₐᵇ [f(x) ± g(x)]dx = ∫ₐᵇ f(x)dx ± ∫ₐᵇ g(x)dx
4. ∫ₐᵇ kf(x)dx = k∫ₐᵇ f(x)dx
5. ∫ₐᵃ f(x)dx = 0
formulas.explanation: Fundamental properties of definite integrals

formulas.title: Even and Odd Functions
formulas.formula:

For odd f(x): ∫₋ₐᵃ f(x)dx = 0
formulas.explanation: Simplification of definite integrals for even and odd functions

formulas.title: Periodic Functions

∫₀^{nT} f(x)dx = n∫₀ᵀ f(x)dx
∫_a^{a+T} f(x)dx = ∫_0^T f(x)dx
formulas.explanation: Properties for integrating periodic functions

notes.title: Understanding Area Under Curves
points: The definite integral ∫ₐᵇf(x)dx represents the signed area between the curve y = f(x), the x-axis, and the vertical lines x = a and x = b.
When f(x) is above the x-axis, the area is positive; when below, it's negative.
To find the total area (always positive), take the absolute value of the integral for each interval where f(x) changes sign.
For curves given in parametric form x = g(t), y = h(t), the area is ∫ₜ₁ᵗ² y(dx/dt)dt = ∫ₜ₁ᵗ² h(t)g'(t)dt.

notes.title: Standard Results and Techniques
points: For even functions (f(-x) = f(x)): ∫₋ₐᵃ f(x)dx = 2∫₀ᵃ f(x)dx
For odd functions (f(-x) = -f(x)): ∫₋ₐᵃ f(x)dx = 0
For periodic functions with period T: ∫₀ⁿᵀ f(x)dx = n∫₀ᵀ f(x)dx where n is an integer
When the curve is given in polar form r = f(θ), the area is ½∫ₐᵇ [f(θ)]² dθ

formulas.title: Area Under a Curve
formulas.explanation: The absolute value ensures the area is always positive, regardless of whether the curve is above or below the x-axis

formulas.title: Area Bounded by y = f(x), x-axis, and x = a, x = b

formulas.title: Area Bounded by x = g(y), y-axis, and y = c, y = d
formulas.explanation: When g(y) ≥ 0 for all y in [c,d]

notes.title: Vertical Strips Method
points: When both curves are functions of x (y = f(x) and y = g(x)), and f(x) ≥ g(x) in [a,b].
The area between them is given by ∫ₐᵇ [f(x) - g(x)] dx.
If the curves intersect within [a,b], find the points of intersection and split the integral accordingly.
Always subtract the lower curve from the upper curve to ensure a positive area.

notes.title: Horizontal Strips Method
points: When both curves are functions of y (x = f(y) and x = g(y)), and f(y) ≥ g(y) in [c,d].
The area between them is given by ∫_c^d [f(y) - g(y)] dy.
This method is particularly useful when it's easier to express x as a function of y.
The choice between vertical and horizontal strips depends on which makes the integral simpler to evaluate.

notes.title: Polar Coordinates
points: For polar curves r = f(θ) and r = g(θ), where f(θ) ≥ g(θ) for α ≤ θ ≤ β.
The area between them is ½∫_α^β [f(θ)² - g(θ)²] dθ.
This is particularly useful for curves that are more naturally expressed in polar coordinates.
Common examples include cardioids, limaçons, and rose curves.

formulas.explanation: For curves y = f(x) and y = g(x) between x = a and x = b

formulas.title: Area Between Two Curves (Horizontal Strips)
formulas.explanation: For curves x = f(y) and x = g(y) between y = c and y = d

formulas.title: Area Between Polar Curves
formulas.explanation: For polar curves r = f(θ) and r = g(θ) between θ = α and θ = β

formulas.title: Area Enclosed by a Parametric Curve
formulas.formula: Area = ∫_α^β y(t) x'(t) dt = -∫_α^β x(t) y'(t) dt
formulas.explanation: For a parametric curve (x(t), y(t)) where t ranges from α to β

topics.name: Order and Degree of Differential Equations

notes.title: Basic Concepts of Differential Equations
points: A differential equation is an equation involving derivatives of a dependent variable with respect to one or more independent variables.
Ordinary Differential Equation (ODE): Contains derivatives with respect to only one independent variable.
Partial Differential Equation (PDE): Contains partial derivatives with respect to more than one independent variable.
The order of a differential equation is the order of the highest order derivative present in the equation.
The degree of a differential equation is the power of the highest order derivative when the equation is made free from radicals and fractions.

notes.title: Examples of Differential Equations
points: First Order: dy/dx + y = eˣ (Order = 1, Degree = 1)
Second Order: d²y/dx² + 3(dy/dx) + 2y = 0 (Order = 2, Degree = 1)
Higher Order: (d³y/dx³)² + (d²y/dx²)³ + y = 0 (Order = 3, Degree = 2)
Non-linear: (d²y/dx²)³ + y(dy/dx)² + y² = 0

formulas.title: General Form of nth Order ODE
formulas.explanation: Where n is the order of the differential equation

formulas.title: Linear Differential Equation
formulas.explanation: Where aₙ(x) ≠ 0 and the dependent variable y and its derivatives appear to the first power only

notes.title: Elimination of Arbitrary Constants
points: A relation involving variables and n arbitrary constants can form an nth order differential equation.
Differentiate the given equation n times to eliminate n arbitrary constants.
Example: For y = Aeˣ + Be⁻ˣ, first find y' and y'' to eliminate A and B.
The resulting equation will be free from arbitrary constants.

notes.title: Geometric Applications
points: Form differential equations of families of curves.
Example: For the family of circles x² + y² = a², the differential equation is x + y(dy/dx) = 0.
For orthogonal trajectories, replace dy/dx with -dx/dy in the differential equation.
The order of the differential equation depends on the number of parameters in the family of curves.

formulas.title: General Procedure
formulas.formula:
1. Differentiate the given equation n times to eliminate n arbitrary constants
2. Eliminate the constants from the (n+1) equations
3. The resulting equation is the required differential equation
formulas.explanation: Process to form a differential equation from a given relation

formulas.title: Orthogonal Trajectories
formulas.formula: If dy/dx = f(x,y) is the differential equation of a family of curves, then dy/dx = -1/f(x,y) is the differential equation of its orthogonal trajectories.
formulas.explanation: For finding curves that intersect the given family at right angles

notes.title: Methods of Solving First Order ODEs
points: Variable Separable: Equations of the form f(x)dx = g(y)dy can be solved by direct integration.
Homogeneous Equations: Can be reduced to variable separable form using substitution y = vx.
Linear Equations: First order linear equations of the form dy/dx + P(x)y = Q(x) can be solved using integrating factor.
Exact Equations: M(x,y)dx + N(x,y)dy = 0 is exact if ∂M/∂y = ∂N/∂x.

notes.title: Second Order Linear Equations
points: General form: a(d²y/dx²) + b(dy/dx) + cy = 0, where a, b, c are constants.
Auxiliary equation: am² + bm + c = 0.
If roots are real and distinct (m₁, m₂): y = C₁e^(m₁x) + C₂e^(m₂x)
If roots are real and equal (m): y = (C₁ + C₂x)e^(mx)
If roots are complex (α ± iβ): y = e^(αx)(C₁cosβx + C₂sinβx)

notes.title: Particular Solutions
points: General solution contains arbitrary constants.
Particular solution is obtained by substituting initial or boundary conditions.
Initial value problems specify the value of the function and its derivatives at a particular point.
Boundary value problems specify the function values at different points.

formulas.title: Integrating Factor Method
formulas.formula: For dy/dx + P(x)y = Q(x), the solution is y(I.F.) = ∫Q(I.F.)dx + C, where I.F. = e^(∫Pdx)
formulas.explanation: Method for solving first order linear differential equations

formulas.title: Method of Undetermined Coefficients
formulas.formula: For non-homogeneous equations, find y_c (complementary function) and y_p (particular integral). The general solution is y = y_c + y_p.
formulas.explanation: Used for solving non-homogeneous linear differential equations with constant coefficients

formulas.title: Variation of Parameters
formulas.formula: For a second order equation y'' + P(x)y' + Q(x)y = R(x), the particular solution is y_p = -y₁∫(y₂R/W)dx + y₂∫(y₁R/W)dx, where W is the Wronskian of y₁ and y₂.
formulas.explanation: General method for finding particular solutions to non-homogeneous equations

notes.title: Understanding Vectors and Scalars
points: Scalar quantities have only magnitude (e.g., mass, temperature, time).
Vector quantities have both magnitude and direction (e.g., displacement, velocity, force).
Vectors are represented by directed line segments with an arrow indicating direction.
The length of the vector represents its magnitude, and the arrow indicates its direction.
Two vectors are equal if they have the same magnitude and direction, regardless of their initial points.

notes.title: Types of Vectors
points: Zero Vector: A vector with zero magnitude and no specific direction (denoted by 0).
Unit Vector: A vector with magnitude 1, used to indicate direction (denoted by â for a unit vector in the direction of a).
Position Vector: A vector representing the position of a point in space relative to an origin.
Co-initial Vectors: Vectors having the same initial point.
Collinear Vectors: Vectors that are parallel to the same line, regardless of their magnitudes and direction.

formulas.title: Magnitude of a Vector
formulas.explanation: For a vector a = xî + yĵ + zk̂, the magnitude is given by the square root of the sum of the squares of its components.

formulas.title: Unit Vector Formula
formulas.explanation: A unit vector in the direction of vector a is obtained by dividing the vector by its magnitude.

notes.title: Triangle Law of Vector Addition
points: If two vectors are represented in magnitude and direction by two sides of a triangle taken in order, then their sum is represented by the third side taken in the opposite order.
For vectors a and b, the sum a + b is represented by the third side of the triangle formed by placing the initial point of b at the terminal point of a.
This method is also known as the head-to-tail method.

notes.title: Parallelogram Law of Vector Addition
points: If two vectors are represented in magnitude and direction by two adjacent sides of a parallelogram, then their sum is represented by the diagonal of the parallelogram through their common point.
This method is particularly useful when vectors are represented with the same initial point.
The commutative property holds: a + b = b + a

notes.title: Properties of Vector Addition
points: Commutative Property: a + b = b + a
Associative Property: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)
Additive Identity: a + 0 = a
Additive Inverse: a + (-a) = 0

formulas.title: Component-wise Addition

notes.title: Understanding Dot Product
points: The dot product of two vectors a and b is defined as a · b = |a||b|cosθ, where θ is the angle between them.
It results in a scalar quantity, not a vector.
The dot product is commutative: a · b = b · a
The dot product of perpendicular vectors is zero.
The dot product of a vector with itself gives the square of its magnitude: a · a = |a|²

notes.title: Properties of Dot Product
points: Distributive over addition: a · (b + c) = a · b + a · c
Scalar multiplication: (k₁a) · (k₂b) = k₁k₂(a · b)
If two vectors are parallel, their dot product equals the product of their magnitudes.
If two vectors are perpendicular, their dot product is zero.

formulas.title: Dot Product in Component Form
formulas.explanation: For vectors a = a₁î + a₂ĵ + a₃k̂ and b = b₁î + b₂ĵ + b₃k̂

notes.title: Understanding Cross Product
points: The cross product of two vectors a and b is a vector perpendicular to both a and b.
Its magnitude is |a × b| = |a||b|sinθ, where θ is the angle between a and b.
The direction is given by the right-hand rule.
The cross product is anti-commutative: a × b = - (b × a)
The cross product of parallel vectors is the zero vector.

notes.title: Properties of Cross Product
points: Distributive over addition: a × (b + c) = a × b + a × c
Scalar multiplication: (k₁a) × (k₂b) = k₁k₂(a × b)
a × a = 0 for any vector a
The magnitude of a × b gives the area of the parallelogram formed by a and b

notes.title: Geometric Interpretation
points: The magnitude of the cross product |a × b| equals the area of the parallelogram formed by vectors a and b.
The direction of a × b is perpendicular to the plane containing a and b, following the right-hand rule.
Three vectors a, b, and c are coplanar if a · (b × c) = 0.

notes.title: Understanding Direction Cosines
points: Direction cosines are the cosines of the angles that a line makes with the positive directions of the coordinate axes.
For a line with direction ratios <a, b, c>, the direction cosines (l, m, n) are given by l = a/√(a² + b² + c²), m = b/√(a² + b² + c²), n = c/√(a² + b² + c²).
The sum of the squares of direction cosines is always 1: l² + m² + n² = 1.

notes.title: Properties of Direction Ratios
points: Direction ratios are proportional to direction cosines.
If <a, b, c> are direction ratios, then <ka, kb, kc> represent the same direction for any non-zero k.
Direction ratios of a line joining two points P(x₁, y₁, z₁) and Q(x₂, y₂, z₂) are <x₂-x₁, y₂-y₁, z₂-z₁>.

notes.title: Vector Form of Line Equation
points: A line passing through a point A with position vector a and parallel to vector b is given by r = a + λb, where λ is a scalar parameter.
The line passes through all points whose position vectors satisfy this equation for some value of λ.
The vector b is called the direction vector of the line.

notes.title: Cartesian Form of Line Equation
points: The line passing through (x₁, y₁, z₁) with direction ratios <a, b, c> has equation: (x - x₁)/a = (y - y₁)/b = (z - z₁)/c.
This is called the symmetric form of the line equation.
The parametric form is: x = x₁ + aλ, y = y₁ + bλ, z = z₁ + cλ.

notes.title: Different Forms of Plane Equations
points: General Form: ax + by + cz + d = 0, where <a, b, c> is the normal vector to the plane.

notes.title: Plane Through Three Points

The angle between two planes is equal to the angle between their normal vectors.

notes.title: Understanding Skew Lines
points: Skew lines are lines in three-dimensional space that are neither parallel nor intersecting.
They lie in different planes and are not parallel to each other.

notes.title: Distance Calculation Methods

Alternatively, it can be found using the scalar triple product formula.
For lines (x-x₁)/a₁ = (y-y₁)/b₁ = (z-z₁)/c₁ and (x-x₂)/a₂ = (y-y₂)/b₂ = (z-z₂)/c₂, the distance is given by a specific determinant formula.

notes.title: Understanding Conditional Probability
points: Conditional probability is the probability of an event occurring given that another event has already occurred.
Notation: P(A|B) represents the probability of event A given that event B has occurred.
Formula: P(A|B) = P(A ∩ B) / P(B), where P(B) ≠ 0.
Independent events: If A and B are independent, P(A|B) = P(A).

notes.title: Properties of Conditional Probability
points: 0 ≤ P(A|B) ≤ 1 for any event A.
P(S|B) = 1, where S is the sample space.
If A₁, A₂, ... are mutually exclusive events, P(A₁ ∪ A₂ ∪ ... |B) = P(A₁|B) + P(A₂|B) + ...

formulas.title: Conditional Probability Formula
formulas.explanation: The probability of event A occurring given that B has already occurred.

formulas.title: Multiplication Rule
formulas.formula: P(A ∩ B) = P(A|B) × P(B) = P(B|A) × P(A)
formulas.explanation: Relates joint probability to conditional probability.

notes.title: Multiplication Theorem for Independent Events
points: For independent events A and B: P(A ∩ B) = P(A) × P(B).
For n independent events: P(A₁ ∩ A₂ ∩ ... ∩ Aₙ) = P(A₁) × P(A₂) × ... × P(Aₙ).

notes.title: General Multiplication Theorem
points: For any two events A and B: P(A ∩ B) = P(A) × P(B|A) = P(B) × P(A|B).
For three events A, B, and C: P(A ∩ B ∩ C) = P(A) × P(B|A) × P(C|A ∩ B).

formulas.title: General Multiplication Rule

notes.title: Understanding Bayes' Theorem
points: Bayes' Theorem relates the conditional and marginal probabilities of random events.
It provides a way to update the probability of an event based on new information.
The theorem is fundamental in Bayesian statistics and has wide applications in various fields.

notes.title: Components of Bayes' Theorem
points: Prior Probability (P(A)): Initial probability of an event before new data.
Likelihood (P(B|A)): Probability of the evidence given the event.
Marginal Probability (P(B)): Total probability of the evidence.
Posterior Probability (P(A|B)): Updated probability after considering the evidence.

formulas.title: Bayes' Theorem Formula
formulas.explanation: Relates the conditional and marginal probabilities of random events.

points: A random variable is a variable whose possible values are numerical outcomes of a random phenomenon.
Discrete Random Variables: Take on a countable number of distinct values.
Continuous Random Variables: Can take on any value in an interval or collection of intervals.

notes.title: Probability Distribution
points: For discrete variables: Probability Mass Function (PMF) gives P(X = x).
For continuous variables: Probability Density Function (PDF) gives the relative likelihood.
Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF) gives P(X ≤ x).

formulas.title: Expected Value (Mean)
formulas.formula: E(X) = Σ [x × P(X=x)] (discrete) or ∫ x × f(x) dx (continuous)
formulas.explanation: The long-run average value of repetitions of the experiment it represents.

formulas.title: Variance
formulas.explanation: Measures how far a set of numbers are spread out from their average value.

realworld.title: Insurance
realworld.description: Insurance companies use random variables to model potential claims and calculate appropriate premiums.

realworld.title: Stock Market
realworld.description: Random variables model stock price movements, helping investors assess risk and potential returns.

notes.title: Binomial Distribution
points: Models the number of successes in a fixed number of independent Bernoulli trials.
Parameters: n (number of trials) and p (probability of success).
Example: Number of heads in 10 coin tosses.

notes.title: Poisson Distribution
points: Models the number of events occurring in a fixed interval of time or space.
Parameter: λ (average rate of occurrence).
Example: Number of calls received by a call center per hour.

notes.title: Normal Distribution
points: Continuous distribution with a bell-shaped curve.
Parameters: μ (mean) and σ (standard deviation).
Approximately 68% of data falls within 1σ, 95% within 2σ, and 99.7% within 3σ of the mean.

formulas.explanation: Probability of k events occurring in a fixed interval.
